Instead of downvoting this with -1 without an explanation I think it would be good if contributors specified WHY they are downvoting this patch. Without such an explanation the auther will have no way of knowing what needs to improve without asking the downvoters. This is addressed by the OpenStack foundation in documentation at least several times but seeing how this patch now has 4 downvotes without explanation I found it important to address this.'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2021-07-05 07:19:44.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Dantali0n.'}]

I'm -2ing this so we can consider the security implications. It looks to me like this allows arbitrary files to be specified by an API user to be included in the ramdisk, potentially allowing any file to be exfiltrated off a conductor node. There doesn't seem to be any validation for the file being a valid cert, in ironic or proliantutils python library.

A possible approach to mitigating this is a new mandatory conf value which is a certificate directory path like /etc/pki, and any requested cert file must be inside this path?"}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-04-06 01:48:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The cert files are read into memory then encoded as json[1] so there is potential for out-of-memory DOS also'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-04-06 01:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> The cert files are read into memory then encoded as json[1] so there is potential for out-of-memory DOS also

[1] https://opendev.org/x/proliantutils/src/branch/master/proliantutils/redfish/redfish.py#L1657'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-08 04:48:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2
> 
> I'm -2ing this so we can consider the security implications. It looks to me like this allows arbitrary files to be specified by an API user to be included in the ramdisk, potentially allowing any file to be exfiltrated off a conductor node. There doesn't seem to be any validation for the file being a valid cert, in ironic or proliantutils python library.
> 
This feature adds the ability to export 3rd party root CAs to iLO so that when iLO tries to boot an ISO hosted in a TLS powered webserver configured with 3rd party certificate the certificate verification passes. These certificates are never injected into the deploy ramdisk. Particularly in the case of ilo-uefi-https boot interface deploy ISO boot requires this.

> A possible approach to mitigating this is a new mandatory conf value which is a certificate directory path like /etc/pki, and any requested cert file must be inside this path?

The users may not have access to /etc/pki and so this restricts them from managing the certificates of interest. I am open to consider this option though but just putting my thoughts out."}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-08 04:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> The cert files are read into memory then encoded as json[1] so there is potential for out-of-memory DOS also

I agree but using a certificate bundle(multiple certificates in a single file) is not very uncommon and this issue is not just limited to this case but everywhere when we specify CA bundle. And in those cases requests library takes care of parsing the CA bundle. In our case(referring to the code that you have pointed), we are required to parse the file for multiple certificates since we needed a specific format of data. I am open to restrict the user to only specify one certificate per file though. In this case i think we need to put a note in the documentation of the feature that only one certificate is allowed per file. WDYT?'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-08 05:02:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> (2 comments)
> 
> Greetings, It looks like this is missing the wallaby release, however if you can make an operational case for operators *needing* the functionality, we're open to discussing backporting if so required.
> 
> That being said, I'd like a little bit of documentation to be added with this patch and the release note to be a little more verbose. I don't have a clear understanding of what/how the settings need to be to use this, much less really how, and if I don't have a clear picture, operators surely be in a worse place.

Thanks Julia. There are two patches for managing the certificates. While this patch adds the certificates to iLO the other patch takes care of removing the certificates specified by the user. The other patch is a dependent patch on this. I am going to update the documentation as part of the dependent path. I will upload a new patchset after updating your other review comments."}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-08 05:04:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks Julia and Steve for the reviews. I have responded to the comments.'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-04-08 22:48:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2
> > 
> > I'm -2ing this so we can consider the security implications. It looks to me like this allows arbitrary files to be specified by an API user to be included in the ramdisk, potentially allowing any file to be exfiltrated off a conductor node. There doesn't seem to be any validation for the file being a valid cert, in ironic or proliantutils python library.
> > 
> This feature adds the ability to export 3rd party root CAs to iLO so that when iLO tries to boot an ISO hosted in a TLS powered webserver configured with 3rd party certificate the certificate verification passes. These certificates are never injected into the deploy ramdisk. Particularly in the case of ilo-uefi-https boot interface deploy ISO boot requires this.

This sounds like it is possible to include file contents from the controller node in an API call to an arbitrary endpoint. This is still not good.

> > A possible approach to mitigating this is a new mandatory conf value which is a certificate directory path like /etc/pki, and any requested cert file must be inside this path?
> 
> The users may not have access to /etc/pki and so this restricts them from managing the certificates of interest. I am open to consider this option though but just putting my thoughts out.

I would assume the users do not have access to any file path on the controller nodes. So if a user has a need to use a 3rd party root CA they would send it to the cloud admin, who will deploy it to every conductor node and respond with a path to use. This path will start with something like /etc/pki, and the conductor will enforce and fail any attempts to specify paths not inside this. Cloud admin policy will determine whether the path is /etc/pki or something else, that is why its an ironic config option."}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2021-04-08 22:51:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> > Patch Set 3:
> > 
> > The cert files are read into memory then encoded as json[1] so there is potential for out-of-memory DOS also
> 
> I agree but using a certificate bundle(multiple certificates in a single file) is not very uncommon and this issue is not just limited to this case but everywhere when we specify CA bundle. And in those cases requests library takes care of parsing the CA bundle. In our case(referring to the code that you have pointed), we are required to parse the file for multiple certificates since we needed a specific format of data. I am open to restrict the user to only specify one certificate per file though. In this case i think we need to put a note in the documentation of the feature that only one certificate is allowed per file. WDYT?

I just meant that allowing arbitrary paths as DOS risk as well as exfiltration risk. Both issues go away when the allowed paths are restricted.'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-14 04:20:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-04-14 05:21:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 19339, 'date': '2021-04-14 06:01:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thank you Vinay.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-06-07 13:40:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Greetings!

At a minimum, we need to see documentation merged with such a change. Even if it is a "oh, there is this clean step for this purpose." Above and beyond documentation, the name of the step is confusing as it is named export, however it is importing certificates to a machine. It may be uploading them *from* the conductor, but even then, that seems confusing. Given some of the assumptions and naming encoded into the code, it seems reasonable that documentation is merged with this change, and I encourage you to re-evaluate the name of the step. A few comments/questions in-line.'}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2021-06-07 15:20:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review

Removing +2 for visibility of the review comments.'}, {'account_id': 18781, 'date': '2021-06-11 12:18:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Support clean/deploy step to add certificates to iLO

Adds 3rd party CA certificates placed in the directory
configured with config option "ilo_ca_certs_dir" to the iLO.

Change-Id: Iac191fb453f8b0844ea1e46937211f8222e7bc63
Story: #2008784
Task: #42175

subject: Support clean/deploy step to remove certificates from iLO

commit_message:
Duplicate notifications are sent when deleting mysql user

In the logic of deleting mysql_user,trove.extensions.mysql.models send a StartNotification which is the same as the StartNotification in trove.extensions.mysql.service

Fix:delete the StartNotification in function trove.extensions.mysql.models.Users.delete

task: 42764
story: 2009029
Change-Id: Ie71a8776032d535248d39fa12386acda8045ad2c

commit_message:
Set fixture paths for unit tests

This change defines manifest_dir and module_path expicitly in unit
tests so that modules installed under fixtures directory is properly
loaded.

When progressmonitor is in restart_progresses function, before send a notification, there is no need to compare retries count with restart_retries.

commit_message:
Remove an useless if judgment in restart_processes

When progressmonitor is in restart_progresses function, before send a notification, there is no need to compare retries count with restart_retries.

Change-Id: Idd3ade35ee012bde3e5de8d7e1be07fd22ef2439

subject: Revert "Install rng-tools in Red Hat family distro images"
messages:
[{'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-06-24 01:32:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-06-29 09:42:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If I don't hear otherwise I plan to merge this.  No response from upstream yet, and there seems to be little other chance of getting containerised installation of this happy (even if upstream responded, we'd have to wait for centos to refresh at least).  Currently it is blocking the dib gate, and image building is paused in production for this issue."}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2021-06-29 10:00:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> If I don't hear otherwise I plan to merge this.  No response from upstream yet, and there seems to be little other chance of getting containerised installation of this happy (even if upstream responded, we'd have to wait for centos to refresh at least).  Currently it is blocking the dib gate, and image building is paused in production for this issue.

well, it would affect Octavia Amphora images, they rely on rng-tools. I will impact boot time (we use encrypted tmpfs to store secrets) and TLS connections in the amphora."}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-06-29 10:50:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:

> well, it would affect Octavia Amphora images, they rely on rng-tools. I will impact boot time (we use encrypted tmpfs to store secrets) and TLS connections in the amphora.

I think we have to consider building in a container a lowest-common denominator these days.  I guess Octavia builds native and doesn't get affected by this.  But Octavia can install this in its own elements/packed installs right?  It doesn't need to be in dib.  Another option is a completely separate element that we don't gate test/use in opendev production"}, {'account_id': 29244, 'date': '2021-06-29 11:27:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> 
> > well, it would affect Octavia Amphora images, they rely on rng-tools. I will impact boot time (we use encrypted tmpfs to store secrets) and TLS connections in the amphora.
> 
> I think we have to consider building in a container a lowest-common denominator these days.  I guess Octavia builds native and doesn't get affected by this.  But Octavia can install this in its own elements/packed installs right?  It doesn't need to be in dib.  Another option is a completely separate element that we don't gate test/use in opendev production

Yeah, installing rng-tools from the elements defined in Octavia would be a work-around if this commit is merged."}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2021-06-29 16:48:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This will tank CentOS/RHEL boot time performance by removing this. As we saw starting with CentOS 8, more of the boot time services and kernel modules rely on the entropy pool now. The kernel pretty much empties it, which causes the other boot time services to stall waiting for enough entropy. The recommended workaround was to add this package to seed the entropy pool with a hardware random number generator provided via qemu.

Have you considered mapping in the hwrng device into the container?
--device /dev/hwrng:/dev/hwrng:r

Really, I agree that this package should probably not use the --settle flag and block on the kernel hw_random device. But that is the point of the BZ.

Some background on this package:
https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2017/10/05/entropy-rhel-based-cloud-instances#what_is_entropy_and_why_is_important_'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-07-02 05:26:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

Ok, it looks like a possible workaround is mounting /sys RO which signals to things such as systemd/udevadm/dbus/whatever-the-hell-magic-happens-these-days that we're in a container.

I need to test more but

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/799126

is promising"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2021-07-05 03:37:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/diskimage-builder/+/799126'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-24 01:32:16.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Install rng-tools in Red Hat family distro images"

This reverts commit 3ff7365ee82fb7664c8fa4619dc47435dea8e222.

It seems like recent versions of this can not be installed in a
container as it tries to run udevadm settle from the RPM post script,
which just hangs forever.

This is mostly an attempt to unbreak the gate.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975588

Change-Id: Iad0794d4e658b763685f274de690e5bcea055dbe
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Install rng-tools in Red Hat family distro images"

This reverts commit 3ff7365ee82fb7664c8fa4619dc47435dea8e222.

It seems like recent versions of this can not be installed in a
container as it tries to run udevadm settle from the RPM post script,
which just hangs forever.

This is mostly an attempt to unbreak the gate.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1975588

Change-Id: Iad0794d4e658b763685f274de690e5bcea055dbe

commit_message:
Add support for independent manila-dashboard configurations

This change introduces the new horizon::dashboards::manila class,
which allows users to manage the independent configuration file for
manila dashboard (_90_manila_shares.py).

Conflicts:
        manifests/params.pp

Change-Id: Ie1442d34b6837ced5f44018d038d4d716d568655
(cherry picked from commit a7d71fb37d7638d19f9ba22650a49c93b2be9142)

commit_message:
Add support for independent octavia-dashboard configurations

This change introduces the new horizon::dashboards::octavia class,
which allows users to manage the independent configuration file for
octavia dashboard (_1499_load_balancer_settings.py).

Conflicts:
	manifests/params.pp

Change-Id: I54f7fb778bc2487bf977e23e193773d627d91dd9
(cherry picked from commit c29622ee456494e6a34f62ded5747585a7ec5e62)

commit_message:
Victoria and before: Use libvirt-daemon-system in Ubuntu Focal

... because libvirt-bin is no longer available since Focal(20.04).
This was fixed by e32576aebc31311e6dbc76b12e6a782481633fe8 during
Wallaby cycle.

Closes-Bug: #1933978
Change-Id: I66f14ec424f9446bf8b5959e25abdbbd3213e51f

commit_message:
Allow setting batch size for expirer

This change introduces a new option to set batch size for expirer,
which allows limiting number of alamr histories purged in a single run.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/755983
Change-Id: Ie37a3c377c455dbafa9cc57ddecb8b8963fc9a82

commit_message:
[stable-only] Cap hacking

With the latest hacking release, 4.1.0, the pep8 test started to fail
with the following errors:

H216: The unittest.mock module should be used rather than the third
party mock

This patch cap hacking<4.1.0 to unblock the gate.

Change-Id: Ia3346187e13acb880b3447598012f1530856f5c8
(cherry picked from commit b917ca42100572e4af6896d20a47eb806e16acf1)

commit_message:
[stable-only] Cap hacking

With the latest hacking release, 4.1.0, the pep8 test started to fail
with the following errors:

H216: The unittest.mock module should be used rather than the third
party mock

This patch cap hacking<4.1.0 to unblock the gate.

Change-Id: Ia3346187e13acb880b3447598012f1530856f5c8

commit_message:
Add parameters for image copy when using multiple RBD Glance stores

Expose the Nova config options to allow an image to be automatically
copied into the local Glance store when Glance is configured to use
multiple RBD stores.

Related Nova change: Ia839ad418b0f2887cb8e8f5ee3e660a0751db9ce

Change-Id: I227f40111591cfe1026ce992b3de3e28d092f329

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-24 14:53:36.000000000', 'message': 'Charter change to handle the vacant seat situation

We had situation in past where we stuck to change the charter
becasue of vacant seat because total number of TC members were
not present to pass the motion.

These type of situation should not hold the TC work and we should
count current number of TC members as complete TC to continue work
on motion, charter etc.

Change-Id: I25c2894a7beb48968edb222cc7ff859fbd392154
'}, {'created': '2021-06-24 15:32:23.000000000', 'message': 'Charter change to handle the vacant seat situation

We had situation in past where we stuck to change the charter
becasue of vacant seat because total number of TC members were
not present to pass the motion.

These type of situation should not hold the TC work and we should
count current number of TC members as complete TC to continue work
on motion, charter etc.

Change-Id: I25c2894a7beb48968edb222cc7ff859fbd392154
'}]
commit_message:
Charter change to handle the vacant seat situation

We had situation in past where we stuck to change the charter
becasue of vacant seat because total number of TC members were
not present to pass the motion.

These type of situation should not hold the TC work and we should
count current number of TC members as complete TC to continue work
on motion, charter etc.

Change-Id: I25c2894a7beb48968edb222cc7ff859fbd392154

See: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/797867 If we delete all the ceph-ansible deployment and environment files, how will the upgrade work?'}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:28:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1
>

This is not going to be backported to Wallaby, and the upgrades to pacific (via ceph-ansible) are from Nautilus to Pacific (which was introduced in Wallaby). Xena's Ceph version is pacific which is managed by cephadm, no need to have any ceph-ansible playbook here."}, {'account_id': 24245, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:30:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

> 
> This is not going to be backported to Wallaby, and the upgrades to pacific (via ceph-ansible) are from Nautilus to Pacific (which was introduced in Wallaby). Xena's Ceph version is pacific which is managed by cephadm, no need to have any ceph-ansible playbook here.

Ah, and as per [1], from Pacific+, upgrades will be managed via cephadm, and they will be probably decoupled from TripleO

commit_message:
Remove from master the ceph-ansible references

ceph-ansible is not used anymore in master and both ceph
deployment and day2 ops are managed by the new cephadm tool.
This change aligns the tripleo-heat-templates tree to make sure
only cephadm is used to deploy Ceph (see [1]).

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-ceph

Change-Id: Ib87615112264bd65e38ed7fb4440cca62f067de5

commit_message:
Fix ipaddress issues in the infinidat driver

In python3.8.11 and python3.9.6, the behavior of the
ipaddress.ip_network.hosts() method changed. Now /32
addresses are returned by that method as a single
element list. This was apparently done as a bugfix [1]

Change-Id: Iab6d96351fa21131d834ccf07ffddd70555f25a7
Closes-Bug: #1934345
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue27683
(cherry picked from commit 1161a56a74b0fd926c20a63242af9dc852f56401)
(cherry picked from commit d015399af51a677ae72e3b56399beaec0dac963d)

commit_message:
directly use files instread of tcib_gather_files

convert tcib_gather_files for kolla related files to install
the openstack-tripleo-common-containers rpm and use those directly
instead of copying into the container image.

Change-Id: I7384243e9e3d804c05fdd1689b6ae3c9306bbb31
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 55b4995110f9da1275a461f16af8b918f2e14059)

Generally when we try the pxe boot of whole disk the chain.c32 tries to load
the MBR, but for the UEFI machines chain.c32 cannot chainload efi-compatible
files. We can set the root and load the bootx64.efi file using chainloader
and boot the machine.

commit_message:
UEFI PXE Provisioning for wholedisk images

Generally when we try the pxe boot of whole disk the chain.c32 tries to load
the MBR, but for the UEFI machines chain.c32 cannot chainload efi-compatible
files. We can set the root and load the bootx64.efi file using chainloader
and boot the machine. '/efi/boot/bootx64.efi' is deafult bootfile, by using
'WHOLEDISK_BOOTFILE' option under 'PXE' section the deafult bootfile can be
changed.

Depends-On: I9882a81ae6d476fd26f3fe0dc00f6072454e3e5a
Change-Id: Ib450a311a62fd691b910ac4de1c74066b8ca6843
Story: 2005532
Task: 30662

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-05-11 14:38:01.000000000', 'message': "Update SRIOV port pci_slot when unshelving

There are a few things we need to do to make that work:

* Always set the PCIRequest's requester_id. Previously, this was only
  done for resource requests. The requester_id is the port UUID, so we
  can use that to correlate which port to update with which pci_slot
  (in the case of multiple SRIOV ports per instance).

  This has the side effect of making the fix work only for instances
  created *after* this patch has been applied. It's not ideal, but
  there does not appear to be a better way.

* Call setup_networks_on_host() within the instance_claim context.
  This means the instance's pci_devices are updated when we call it,
  allowing us to get the pci_slot information from them.

With the two previous changes in place, we can figure out the port's
new pci_slot in _update_port_binding_for_instance().

Closes: bug 1851545
Change-Id: Icfa8c1d6e84eab758af6223a2870078685584aaa
(cherry picked from commit 00f1d4757e503bb9807d7a8d7035c061a97db983)
"}, {'created': '2021-05-19 18:17:36.000000000', 'message': "Update SRIOV port pci_slot when unshelving

There are a few things we need to do to make that work:

* Always set the PCIRequest's requester_id. Previously, this was only
  done for resource requests. The requester_id is the port UUID, so we
  can use that to correlate which port to update with which pci_slot
  (in the case of multiple SRIOV ports per instance).

  This has the side effect of making the fix work only for instances
  created *after* this patch has been applied. It's not ideal, but
  there does not appear to be a better way.

* Call setup_networks_on_host() within the instance_claim context.
  This means the instance's pci_devices are updated when we call it,
  allowing us to get the pci_slot information from them.

With the two previous changes in place, we can figure out the port's
new pci_slot in _update_port_binding_for_instance().

Closes: bug 1851545
Change-Id: Icfa8c1d6e84eab758af6223a2870078685584aaa
(cherry picked from commit 00f1d4757e503bb9807d7a8d7035c061a97db983)
"}]
commit_message:
Update SRIOV port pci_slot when unshelving

There are a few things we need to do to make that work:

* Always set the PCIRequest's requester_id. Previously, this was only
  done for resource requests. The requester_id is the port UUID, so we
  can use that to correlate which port to update with which pci_slot
  (in the case of multiple SRIOV ports per instance).

  This has the side effect of making the fix work only for instances
  created *after* this patch has been applied. It's not ideal, but
  there does not appear to be a better way.

* Call setup_networks_on_host() within the instance_claim context.
  This means the instance's pci_devices are updated when we call it,
  allowing us to get the pci_slot information from them.

With the two previous changes in place, we can figure out the port's
new pci_slot in _update_port_binding_for_instance().

Closes: bug 1851545
Change-Id: Icfa8c1d6e84eab758af6223a2870078685584aaa
(cherry picked from commit 00f1d4757e503bb9807d7a8d7035c061a97db983)

commit_message:
init_host should be called before RPC consumer is created

This change adds a new hook to Manager class called init_host_with_rpc()
to allow services like scheduler to do something once RPC is ready.

Copied from cinder https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/65fa80c361f71158cc492dfc520dc4a63ccfa419
and https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/60c563f72d2d6d008fca03f0a058941f3807e1a8

Change-Id: Iac6507a6e395c55f0fec453650009f08c2bb6563
Closes-Bug: #1271568

commit_message:
[CI] Do not set ansible_python_interpreter for Zuul

Zuul 4.6.0 does not allow to set ansible_python_interpreter. [1]
Instead, with the current Zuul and Ansible, this should be
automatically set to the proper python.

This patch is required to restore the jobs which are ignored
otherwise. [2] [3]

Additionally, this change avoids the use of Ansible's pip
module because it tries to use setuptools from the
ansible_python_interpreter first even if another executable is
set.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023291.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023326.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023321.html

Change-Id: Ib74eecd46617af51e23a3ccad664767b1bf6e04f

commit_message:
Remove leftover of Panko support

... because support for Panko in TripleO was removed during Ussuri
cycle (actually it was removed during Train cycle but removal was
reverted in Train) and Panko itself has been removed

Co-authored-by: Matthias Runge <mrunge@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iadf52ec1cec555e656207cc6279c6b11a9a0887d
(cherry picked from commit 9d7559800624a32f97538b822f8fc3ed2c0eb223)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie85ab9940531e1776d59f4c2e4cb00742ceb33b3

commit_message:
[CI] Do not set ansible_python_interpreter for Zuul

Zuul 4.6.0 does not allow to set ansible_python_interpreter. [1]
Instead, with the current Zuul and Ansible, this should be
automatically set to the proper python.

This patch is required to restore the jobs which are ignored
otherwise. [2] [3]

Additionally, this change avoids the use of Ansible's pip
module because it tries to use setuptools from the
ansible_python_interpreter first even if another executable is
set.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023291.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023326.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2021-June/023321.html

Change-Id: Ib74eecd46617af51e23a3ccad664767b1bf6e04f

commit_message:
Make it possible to override automatic fluentd version detection

One use case for this is so that you can generate config in a CI job
without access to the container repository. It also removes the
dependency of having docker configured for config generation.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I0d388851c8b953af0494e44ae569e7eb9e15c326
(cherry picked from commit 25c33f9c9477c3a7b5f48a50157b16b1b7c595b1)

[{'created': '2021-07-02 02:45:42.000000000', 'message': 'Use explicit order for ironic enabled interfaces

Ironic uses the order of enabled interfaces to attempt each interface
in turn, so sorting the list will result in an incorrect order in some
cases, which will cause deployment failures on some hardware.

This change sets an explicit order for each interface.

(cherry picked from commit 05500120e07311389d6227d5e513fda422844321)
'}]
commit_message:
Use explicit order for ironic enabled interfaces

Ironic uses the order of enabled interfaces to attempt each interface
in turn, so sorting the list will result in an incorrect order in some
cases, which will cause deployment failures on some hardware.

This change sets an explicit order for each interface.

Change-Id: If2740767521453c7adfca56d942db97af13bfaf2
Closes-Bug: #1931161
(cherry picked from commit 05500120e07311389d6227d5e513fda422844321)

commit_message:
directly use files instread of tcib_gather_files

convert tcib_gather_files for kolla related files to install
the openstack-tripleo-common-containers rpm and use those directly
instead of copying into the container image.

Also included same change for ec2-api

Change-Id: I7384243e9e3d804c05fdd1689b6ae3c9306bbb31
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 55b4995110f9da1275a461f16af8b918f2e14059)

[{'created': '2021-06-30 13:10:31.000000000', 'message': 'relinker: tolerate existing tombstone with same X-Timestamp

It is possible for the current and next part power locations to
both have existing tombstones with different inodes when the
relinker tries to relink. This can be caused, for example, by
concurrent reconciler DELETEs that specify the same timestamp.

The relinker previously failed to relink and reported an error when
encountering this situation. With this patch the relinker will
tolerate an existing tombstone with different inode in the next part
power location. The relinker will however first confirm that the
tombstone has the same X-Timestamp in metadata as the tombstone in the

Change-Id: I07ffee3b4ba6c7ff6c206beaf6b8f746fe365c2b
Closes-Bug: #1934142
'}, {'created': '2021-07-01 10:57:44.000000000', 'message': 'relinker: tolerate existing tombstone with same X-Timestamp

It is possible for the current and next part power locations to
both have existing tombstones with different inodes when the
relinker tries to relink. This can be caused, for example, by
concurrent reconciler DELETEs that specify the same timestamp.

The relinker previously failed to relink and reported an error when
encountering this situation. With this patch the relinker will
tolerate an existing tombstone with different inode in the next part
power location. The relinker will however first confirm that the
tombstone has the same X-Timestamp in metadata as the tombstone in the
current part power location.

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

commit_message:
relinker: tolerate existing tombstone with same timestamp

It is possible for the current and next part power locations to
both have existing tombstones with different inodes when the
relinker tries to relink. This can be caused, for example, by
concurrent reconciler DELETEs that specify the same timestamp.

The relinker previously failed to relink and reported an error when
encountering this situation. With this patch the relinker will
tolerate an existing tombstone with the same filename but different
inode in the next part power location.

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

Change-Id: I07ffee3b4ba6c7ff6c206beaf6b8f746fe365c2b
Closes-Bug: #1934142

Thanks Lucio for testing it again :-)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-11-14 18:27:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Are there risks with drivers now getting these requests and not checking for the things they previously hadn't had to worry about?

I think we should raise this in a meeting and try to get more driver maintainer input."}, {'account_id': 32291, 'date': '2020-11-16 09:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2020-11-19 10:08:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Are there risks with drivers now getting these requests and not
 > checking for the things they previously hadn't had to worry about?
 
@smcginnis: The patch only adds calls to the driver assisted migration when there is no difference with a normal migration.  So never when there is a change in specs, qos, or encryption.

So mostly the cases where we are calling the driver now are when we change the Cinder AZ and when the cinder backend name is different. In both cases these are Cinder constructs that can be changed or configured from the start to be the same in both, the source and the destination, backends.

If there is a problem with making this call to a driver, then the bug is in the driver, since it would be making assumptions that it should have never made in the first place.

Please let me know if you still believe that we should discuss it on the Cinder meeting and I'll add it to the next agenda."}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2021-03-22 17:21:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 32418, 'date': '2021-03-22 17:28:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-06 16:33:17.000000000', 'message': "Driver assisted migration on retype when it's safe

When doing a retype of a volume that requires a migration, the manager
only uses driver assisted migration when the source and the destination
belong to the same backend (different pools).

Driver assisted migration should also be tried for other cases, just
like when we do a normal migration.

One case were this would be beneficial is when doing migrations from one
pool to another on the same storage system on single pool drivers (such
as RBD/Ceph).

This patch checks what are the changes between the types to see if it is
safe to use driver assisted migration (from the perspective of keeping
the resulting volume consistent with the volume type) and when it is it
tries to use it.

If driver assisted migration indicates that it couldn't move the volume,
then we go with the generic volume migration like we used to.

Closes-Bug: #1886543
Change-Id: I2532cfc9b98788a1a1e765f07d0c9f8c98bc77f6
"}, {'created': '2020-07-29 09:59:50.000000000', 'message': "Driver assisted migration on retype when it's safe

One case were this would be beneficial is when doing migrations from one
pool to another on the same storage system on single pool drivers (such
as RBD/Ceph).

This patch checks what are the changes between the types to see if it is
safe to use driver assisted migration (from the perspective of keeping

If driver assisted migration indicates that it couldn't move the volume,
then we go with the generic volume migration like we used to.

Closes-Bug: #1886543

"}, {'created': '2020-09-04 10:17:58.000000000', 'message': "Driver assisted migration on retype when it's safe

This patch checks what are the changes between the types to see if it is
safe to use driver assisted migration (from the perspective of keeping
the resulting volume consistent with the volume type) and when it is it
tries to use it.

If driver assisted migration indicates that it couldn't move the volume,
then we go with the generic volume migration like we used to.

Closes-Bug: #1886543
Change-Id: I2532cfc9b98788a1a1e765f07d0c9f8c98bc77f6
"}, {'created': '2021-03-22 17:21:48.000000000', 'message': "Driver assisted migration on retype when it's safe

only uses driver assisted migration when the source and the destination
belong to the same backend (different pools).

Driver assisted migration should also be tried for other cases, just
like when we do a normal migration.

One case were this would be beneficial is when doing migrations from one
pool to another on the same storage system on single pool drivers (such
as RBD/Ceph).

This patch checks what are the changes between the types to see if it is

commit_message:
Driver assisted migration on retype when it's safe

When doing a retype of a volume that requires a migration, the manager
only uses driver assisted migration when the source and the destination
belong to the same backend (different pools).

Driver assisted migration should also be tried for other cases, just
like when we do a normal migration.

One case were this would be beneficial is when doing migrations from one
pool to another on the same storage system on single pool drivers (such
as RBD/Ceph).

This patch checks what are the changes between the types to see if it is
safe to use driver assisted migration (from the perspective of keeping
the resulting volume consistent with the volume type) and when it is it
tries to use it.

If driver assisted migration indicates that it couldn't move the volume,
then we go with the generic volume migration like we used to.

Closes-Bug: #1886543
Change-Id: I2532cfc9b98788a1a1e765f07d0c9f8c98bc77f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-01 15:26:12.000000000', 'message': "Copy existing IPv6 leases to generated lease file

Because the DHCP agent does not know the IAID (identity association
identifier) of assigned IPv6 addresses it's not possible to generate the
lease file including IPv6 leases. Because of this IPv6 addresses are
excluded when generating the lease file in case of DHCP agent restarts.
This causes DHCPv6 clients to fail to RENEW their lease and to go
through a full address discovery cycle with possible short connectivity
disruption.

This commit copies the existing IPv6 leaes from an already existing
lease file if present. While this does not allow for DHCP agent
failover, this is still better than just skipping the IPv6 addresses.

A lease file without the IPv6 addresses is still generated if an agent
is migrated to a different host.

This commit complements the fix implemented in
Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e which just skips the IPv6
leases as otherwise the lease file would be invalid and all leases would
be lost. It does not change the behavior for still valid IPv4 leases.

With this issue fixed an additional fix is required to not loose DHCPv6
leases when the agent restarts dnsmasq. Currently the DHCP agent
regenerates all configuration files on restart. This means that DHCPv6
leases are lost as they can't be regenerated. This changes the agent to
only delete the config files if the agent's ports are also removed.

Closes-Bug: #1722126
Related-Change: Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e

Change-Id: I40761b30563749251b9d74731bbe7a80a124da89
(cherry picked from commit 6bc1c00d66ced82dd142739790222e8408684696)
"}]
commit_message:
Copy existing IPv6 leases to generated lease file

Because the DHCP agent does not know the IAID (identity association
identifier) of assigned IPv6 addresses it's not possible to generate the
lease file including IPv6 leases. Because of this IPv6 addresses are
excluded when generating the lease file in case of DHCP agent restarts.
This causes DHCPv6 clients to fail to RENEW their lease and to go
through a full address discovery cycle with possible short connectivity
disruption.

This commit copies the existing IPv6 leaes from an already existing
lease file if present. While this does not allow for DHCP agent
failover, this is still better than just skipping the IPv6 addresses.

A lease file without the IPv6 addresses is still generated if an agent
is migrated to a different host.

This commit complements the fix implemented in
Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e which just skips the IPv6
leases as otherwise the lease file would be invalid and all leases would
be lost. It does not change the behavior for still valid IPv4 leases.

With this issue fixed an additional fix is required to not loose DHCPv6
leases when the agent restarts dnsmasq. Currently the DHCP agent
regenerates all configuration files on restart. This means that DHCPv6
leases are lost as they can't be regenerated. This changes the agent to
only delete the config files if the agent's ports are also removed.

Closes-Bug: #1722126
Related-Change: Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e

Change-Id: I40761b30563749251b9d74731bbe7a80a124da89
(cherry picked from commit 6bc1c00d66ced82dd142739790222e8408684696)

commit_message:
Add '--templates' arg to node and net provision

Allow setting '--templates', the path tot the THT root
directory. Environment files created by the node and
network provision commands will be created with the user
specified path to the THT root. Defaults to:
 /usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates/

Closes-Bug: #1932079
Depends-On: I9decd8fb9860cd17dc9e69b9970d9f9dabf11428
Change-Id: I5dd81788c08bb0d797190a5fb8bb120b7d8b4f32

commit_message:
Validate the container_cli option

The container_cli option should be set to podman because docker is no
longer supported since Ussuri. This change ensures its value is
validated at parser layer.

commit_message:
Add option to set template paths in env population

Overcloud node and network provisioning plays currently
write environment files with a hard coded THT-root path.

Add 'templates' parameter to the modules so that the user
can specify the templates path.

Related-Bug: #1932079
Change-Id: I9decd8fb9860cd17dc9e69b9970d9f9dabf11428
(cherry picked from commit af92fbc650f74766e9a29a447be807c1e21418af)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-02 02:49:01.000000000', 'message': 'Use explicit order for ironic enabled interfaces

Ironic uses the order of enabled interfaces to attempt each interface
in turn, so sorting the list will result in an incorrect order in some
cases, which will cause deployment failures on some hardware.

This change sets an explicit order for each interface.

Change-Id: If2740767521453c7adfca56d942db97af13bfaf2
Closes-Bug: #1931161
(cherry picked from commit 05500120e07311389d6227d5e513fda422844321)
'}]
commit_message:
Use explicit order for ironic enabled interfaces

Ironic uses the order of enabled interfaces to attempt each interface
in turn, so sorting the list will result in an incorrect order in some
cases, which will cause deployment failures on some hardware.

This change sets an explicit order for each interface.

Change-Id: If2740767521453c7adfca56d942db97af13bfaf2
Closes-Bug: #1931161
(cherry picked from commit 05500120e07311389d6227d5e513fda422844321)

commit_message:
Remove from master the ceph-ansible references

ceph-ansible is not used anymore in master and both ceph
deployment and day2 ops are managed by the new cephadm tool.
This change aligns the existing validations removing the tasks
and the playbooks involving cpeh-ansible (see [1]).

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tripleo/+spec/tripleo-ceph

Change-Id: I6a80870680091c9839efb1f222a6adbdef5b36df

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 23:58:21.000000000', 'message': "Check for no neutron network in inventory

The host network or SSH network specified with --overcloud-ssh-network
may not exist in Neutron. There is no requirement that it does. Add a
check and log a warning instead of trying to use the None object when
the network is not found. When it's not found, neutron data is not added
to the inventory.

Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I20d6ae39511e368e724522d133a133d1c864cb1b
"}]
commit_message:
Check for no neutron network in inventory

The host network or SSH network specified with --overcloud-ssh-network
may not exist in Neutron. There is no requirement that it does. Add a
check and log a warning instead of trying to use the None object when
the network is not found. When it's not found, neutron data is not added
to the inventory.

Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I20d6ae39511e368e724522d133a133d1c864cb1b

commit_message:
Avoid creating multiple entries of udev rules

As on date os-net-config does not support changing numvfs.
However if external scripts are used to reset numvfs to zero and
reconfigure numvfs, the udev rule shall reflect the new numvfs
and the previous udev rule shall be replaced.

Change-Id: I18e65e99b7228d8aea20d510070968f17e021e3c

commit_message:
Coverage change job

Zuul check for changes in unit test coverage.
With this running we can ensure that no more code is
merged without tests.

Checks both per file, and total coverage.

At this stage, I'm proposing is a non-voting job.
After a grace period, for example one sprint or two, it would become voting

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I4a66ab1fca07577ba2d3258222bbdaf63e5adbca

commit_message:
Coverage change job

Zuul check for changes in unit test coverage.
With this running we can ensure that no more code is
merged without tests.

Checks both per file, and total coverage.

At this stage, I'm proposing is a non-voting job.
After a grace period, for example one sprint or two, it would become voting.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Coverage change job

Zuul check for changes in unit test coverage.
With this running we can ensure that no more code is
merged without tests.

Checks both per file, and total coverage.

At this stage, I'm proposing is a non-voting job.
After a grace period, for example one sprint or two, it would become voting.

Signed-off-by: Jiri Podivin <jpodivin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: If2e61c9bbf59e91163357023d16620934dc7d3a0

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-28 19:05:40.000000000', 'message': "Extend UC ephemeral heat to export network

Run the commands to export the current stack's networks,
virtual IPs and provisioned server as part of the
OS::TripleO::UndercloudUpgradeEphemeralHeat service script.

The network, virtual IP definitions and baremeteal deployment
definition will will be stored in each stacks subdirectory in
the working-dir.

The user must provide the path to the roles data file for each
overcloud stack managed by the undercloud being upgraded.
For example, by adding a file with below content and including
this env file using the 'custom_env_files' option in
undercloud.conf.

  parameter_defaults:
    OvercloudStackRoleDataFileMap:
      overcloud: /home/centos/overcloud/my_roles_data.yaml

Related: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: Id04a4f71f923a25fd50ca78e478a9b5abb61bbb9
(cherry picked from commit 28105815c15cd2633accc1a900e7887c83a728af)
"}]
commit_message:
Extend UC ephemeral heat to export network

Run the commands to export the current stack's networks,
virtual IPs and provisioned server as part of the
OS::TripleO::UndercloudUpgradeEphemeralHeat service script.

The network, virtual IP definitions and baremeteal deployment
definition will will be stored in each stacks subdirectory in
the working-dir.

The user must provide the path to the roles data file for each
overcloud stack managed by the undercloud being upgraded.
For example, by adding a file with below content and including
this env file using the 'custom_env_files' option in
undercloud.conf.

  parameter_defaults:
    OvercloudStackRoleDataFileMap:
      overcloud: /home/centos/overcloud/my_roles_data.yaml

Related: blueprint network-data-v2-ports
Change-Id: Id04a4f71f923a25fd50ca78e478a9b5abb61bbb9
(cherry picked from commit 28105815c15cd2633accc1a900e7887c83a728af)

commit_message:
Rebuild venv if missing

If a deployer removes a venv from /openstack/venvs and runs the role
in an attempt to re-deploy the venv from the same tag, the role will
fail. This is because the venv archive in /var/cache is still present
with the same checksum, so the download and extract process is not
triggered.

Change-Id: I06981f5f6f294d20251bc7b9d139d8161beb5ec7

commit_message:
[OVN] neutron-ovn-metadat-agent add retry logic for sb_idl

Add retry logic to retrieve OvsdbSb IDL object.
Add port fork event in MetadataProxyHandler to wait for the
OvsdbSb IDL object.

Closes-Bug: #1928031
Change-Id: Idce1ec4e160c5a7f8532b57f577b9518a06b0dd0

commit_message:
Add user_get_uploading_count() to DB API

This adds an efficient query method for getting a count of the user's
images that are in any state of uploading. This includes images
in the process of saving from upload, staging, importing, or being
copied to another store.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: Iebba15771000e86a0701d20ed9620eb578c2cb85

commit_message:
Make dark data watcher ignore the newly updated objects

When objects are freshly uploaded, they may take a little time
to appear in container listings, producing false positives.

Because we needed to test this, we also reworked/added the tests
and fixed some issues, including adding an EC fragment (thanks
to Alistair's code).

Closes-Bug: 1925782
Change-Id: Ieafa72a496328f7a487ca7062da6253994a5a07d
Co-Authored-By: Alistair Coles <alistairncoles@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add image_count_uploading quota enforcement

This makes us enforce a quota on the total number of upload-related
image operations owned by a user.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I2a28750aaf968e6a6324eb194d4280a640bfa5aa

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-01 22:19:10.000000000', 'message': 'Suppress policy deprecation and default change warnings

As part of the policy defaults refresh work, all of the defaults for
policies were changed and warnings about it are being emitted
constantly in the logs. We can suppress these for now until we are
enforcing new defaults [1].

This also suppresses policy deprecation warnings during tests to avoid
filling the console with warning messages.

Related to blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#oslo_policy.enforce_new_defaults

Change-Id: I4a169b42d516a7ae2adcee9b69d71723fdefcd95
'}]
commit_message:
Suppress policy deprecation and default change warnings

As part of the policy defaults refresh work, all of the defaults for
policies were changed and warnings about it are being emitted
constantly in the logs. We can suppress these for now until we are
enforcing new defaults [1].

This also suppresses policy deprecation warnings during tests to avoid
filling the console with warning messages.

Related to blueprint policy-defaults-refresh

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#oslo_policy.enforce_new_defaults

Change-Id: I4a169b42d516a7ae2adcee9b69d71723fdefcd95

subject: Remove skip_missing_interpreters
messages:
[{'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-06-30 20:37:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-06-30 21:26:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:23:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

python-cinderclient-functional-py36 failure is bindep related, can't find the 'python-devel' package on centos-8-stream"}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:43:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:45:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Updated bindep.txt to the way the bindep project itself specifies the problematic package:
https://opendev.org/opendev/bindep/src/commit/623c2e048640b4895e0e12f4c0ca857f2038f771/bindep/tests/bindep.txt#L7-L8'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-01 15:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck python-cinderclient-functional-py36 - this time the bindep was satisfied and tests ran; failure is an intermittent thing in cinderclient.tests.functional.test_cli.CinderBackupTests.test_backup_create_and_delete, will investigate further'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-07-01 16:25:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2021-07-02 12:42:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 20813, 'date': '2021-07-02 18:56:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

As Brian wrote in the commit msg this isn't a theoretical issue and LGTM."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-30 20:37:47.000000000', 'message': "Remove skip_missing_interpreters

This prevents a job reporting 'success' when the appropriate python
interpreter cannot be found, when actually it didn't run at all.
Also change the default envlist to use generic 'py3' instead of a
specific version which might not be present.

Jeremy Stanley has given a more thorough explanation of why this
is a good change:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014810.html

This isn't a theoretical issue.  If you look at recent
python-cinderclient-functional-py36 job results (for example,
[0]), you'll see that Zuul reported 'success', but on a closer look,
you'll see that no tests were run.

[0] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/1bfc80638086405f8b29905cdd6f71be/log/job-output.txt#25470

Change-Id: I2e2aa24e1592b66b287c84eda97b5079c40a36ec
"}, {'created': '2021-07-01 12:43:15.000000000', 'message': "Remove skip_missing_interpreters

This prevents a job reporting 'success' when the appropriate python
interpreter cannot be found, when actually it didn't run at all.
Also change the default envlist to use generic 'py3' instead of a
specific version which might not be present.

Also change zuul config so the python-cinderclient-functional-py36
job runs on centos-8-stream nodes, where py36 should be available.
And change bindep.txt to specify the correct package name for
centos-8.

Jeremy Stanley has given a more thorough explanation of why this
is a good change:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014810.html

This isn't a theoretical issue.  If you look at recent
python-cinderclient-functional-py36 job results (for example,
[0]), you'll see that Zuul reported 'success', but on a closer look,
you'll see that no tests were run.

[0] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/1bfc80638086405f8b29905cdd6f71be/log/job-output.txt#25470

Change-Id: I2e2aa24e1592b66b287c84eda97b5079c40a36ec

commit_message:
Remove skip_missing_interpreters

This prevents a job reporting 'success' when the appropriate python
interpreter cannot be found, when actually it didn't run at all.
Also change the default envlist to use generic 'py3' instead of a
specific version which might not be present.

Also change zuul config so the python-cinderclient-functional-py36
job runs on centos-8-stream nodes, where py36 should be available.
And change bindep.txt to specify the correct package name for
centos-8.

Jeremy Stanley has given a more thorough explanation of why this
is a good change:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014810.html

This isn't a theoretical issue.  If you look at recent
python-cinderclient-functional-py36 job results (for example,
[0]), you'll see that Zuul reported 'success', but on a closer look,
you'll see that no tests were run.

[0] https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/1bfc80638086405f8b29905cdd6f71be/log/job-output.txt#25470

Change-Id: I2e2aa24e1592b66b287c84eda97b5079c40a36ec

commit_message:
Add route to IPv6 private subnets in ML2/OVN

Enable IPv6 private subnet routing in ML2/OVN, it uses the behavior that
already exists in ML2/OVS: add a route from the devstack node to the
CIDRs of the default IPv6 subnet pool. Any IPv6 subnet created using the
default subnet pool and plugged into the default router is reachable
from the host (ex: ipv6-private-subnet).

Change-Id: I02ca1d94e9f4d5ad4a06182f5ac9a2434941cf08

commit_message:
Add Ceph version check

CephFS drivers in OpenStack Manila are directing
mgr commands to the mgr by specifying mon-mgr as
the target [0]. This target (mon-mgr) was added
to Ceph in Octopus [1].

We would need a version check in order to set the
correct target while we wait on the backport on Ceph
to land [2].

[0] https://github.com/openstack/manila/commit/3ea5d50a2383d298cf64db3c035a63865e091119
[1] https://github.com/ceph/ceph/commit/4000d500c0d2c017e7761a5592df1301d7f40538
[2] https://tracker.ceph.com/issues/51039

Closes-Bug: #1930459
Change-Id: I1a1079df8e104c5ddba29cb614eb4e02a304082e
(cherry picked from commit 3ed02db00e3e8db9712582d00fe65ceefecbf162)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-22 17:07:06.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: reconstructor: Delay purging reverted non-durable datafiles

TODO:
- unit test is_file_older
- fix probe test

The reconstructor may revert a non-durable datafile concurrently with
an object server PUT to the handoff that is about to make the datafile
durable.  This could previously lead to the reconstructor deleting the
recently written datafile before the object-server attempts to rename
it to a durable datafile, and a traceback in the object server.

The reconstructor will now only remove reverted nondurable datafiles
that are older (according to mtime) than a period set by a new
nondurable_purge_delay option (defaults to 60 seconds). More recent
nondurable datafiles may be made durable or will remain on the handoff
until a subsequent reconstructor cycle.

Change-Id: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0

commit_message:
reconstructor: Delay purging reverted non-durable datafiles

The reconstructor may revert a non-durable datafile on a handoff
concurrently with an object server PUT that is about to make the
datafile durable.  This could previously lead to the reconstructor
deleting the recently written datafile before the object-server
attempts to rename it to a durable datafile, and consequently a
traceback in the object server.

The reconstructor will now only remove reverted nondurable datafiles
that are older (according to mtime) than a period set by a new
nondurable_purge_delay option (defaults to 60 seconds). More recent
nondurable datafiles may be made durable or will remain on the handoff
until a subsequent reconstructor cycle.

Change-Id: I0d519ebaaade35249fb7b17bd5f419ffdaa616c0

TrivialFix: Fix the filter name in config helper

The config `use_scheduler_creating_share_from_snapshot` has the
help message with wrong name of the scheduler filter that the user must
enable with the option. The filter name is `CreateFromSnapshotFilter`,
instead of `CreateShareFromSnapshot`.

(cherry picked from commit 854b1dc958db4bd903e7b3c69c242295ad1518bd)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-01 15:23:57.000000000', 'message': "Copy existing IPv6 leases to generated lease file

Because the DHCP agent does not know the IAID (identity association
identifier) of assigned IPv6 addresses it's not possible to generate the
lease file including IPv6 leases. Because of this IPv6 addresses are
excluded when generating the lease file in case of DHCP agent restarts.
This causes DHCPv6 clients to fail to RENEW their lease and to go
through a full address discovery cycle with possible short connectivity
disruption.

This commit copies the existing IPv6 leaes from an already existing
lease file if present. While this does not allow for DHCP agent
failover, this is still better than just skipping the IPv6 addresses.

A lease file without the IPv6 addresses is still generated if an agent
is migrated to a different host.

This commit complements the fix implemented in
Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e which just skips the IPv6
leases as otherwise the lease file would be invalid and all leases would
be lost. It does not change the behavior for still valid IPv4 leases.

With this issue fixed an additional fix is required to not loose DHCPv6
leases when the agent restarts dnsmasq. Currently the DHCP agent
regenerates all configuration files on restart. This means that DHCPv6
leases are lost as they can't be regenerated. This changes the agent to
only delete the config files if the agent's ports are also removed.

Closes-Bug: #1722126
Related-Change: Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e

Change-Id: I40761b30563749251b9d74731bbe7a80a124da89
(cherry picked from commit 6bc1c00d66ced82dd142739790222e8408684696)
"}]
commit_message:
Copy existing IPv6 leases to generated lease file

Because the DHCP agent does not know the IAID (identity association
identifier) of assigned IPv6 addresses it's not possible to generate the
lease file including IPv6 leases. Because of this IPv6 addresses are
excluded when generating the lease file in case of DHCP agent restarts.
This causes DHCPv6 clients to fail to RENEW their lease and to go
through a full address discovery cycle with possible short connectivity
disruption.

This commit copies the existing IPv6 leaes from an already existing
lease file if present. While this does not allow for DHCP agent
failover, this is still better than just skipping the IPv6 addresses.

A lease file without the IPv6 addresses is still generated if an agent
is migrated to a different host.

This commit complements the fix implemented in
Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e which just skips the IPv6
leases as otherwise the lease file would be invalid and all leases would
be lost. It does not change the behavior for still valid IPv4 leases.

With this issue fixed an additional fix is required to not loose DHCPv6
leases when the agent restarts dnsmasq. Currently the DHCP agent
regenerates all configuration files on restart. This means that DHCPv6
leases are lost as they can't be regenerated. This changes the agent to
only delete the config files if the agent's ports are also removed.

Closes-Bug: #1722126
Related-Change: Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e

Change-Id: I40761b30563749251b9d74731bbe7a80a124da89
(cherry picked from commit 6bc1c00d66ced82dd142739790222e8408684696)

commit_message:
Remove NovaVncProxyNetwork from ServiceNetMap

In Icef2481b65b41b524ad44eeecfbee4451006e1d2 we moved to use
NovaLibvirtNetwork as the single network to configure instance console
components.
Due to how hieradata is being rendered via tripleo-hieradata, the
removed NovaVncProxyNetwork resulted in no-vnc-proxy service to
fall back to the control plane network because NovaVncProxyNetwork
was removed.
NovaVncProxyNetwork was then reintroduced with
I595294956a4a7a0e2280c685ac1d2543edbc32f2 but as a side effect
again introduced the inconsistency on the console configuration.

This patch removes the NovaVncProxyNetwork from ServiceNetMap
but set it as part of service_net_map.j2.yaml and keep it in
sync with NovaLibvirtNetwork.

Conflicts:
    network/service_net_map.j2.yaml
    overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml

Change-Id: I08fa1ee947574e6fac24885b17706a22054fcba9
Closes-Bug: #1917719
(cherry picked from commit 9da8a405952623e42f52e13ac948da1e57cf6906)

commit_message:
CI use '--skip-nodes-and-networks' in oc deploy

Since the CI run's the commands to provision networks,
virtual IPs and baremetal nodes individually prior to
running overcloud deploy we can disable these steps
when running overcloud deploy.

NOTE: 'network_provison' is only set to True for Wallaby
and later releases.

Depends-On: I2fa073863f2d292575ee1dbdc0da271434f219f6
Change-Id: I8008344f215be6a54e00d7d27b697375b7f88f0f

[{'created': '2021-07-02 11:50:53.000000000', 'message': 'import "collections.abc" explicitly

The Collections Abstract Base Classes is moved to the
collections.abc module, which was earlier part of the
collections module[1].

The python3 reports a warning for the same-
DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from
'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is
deprecated since Python 3.3, and in 3.10 it will stop working.

This patch updates to import collection.abc module explicitly.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html

Change-Id: I18ba70140f9b2b53f2e97e70f64973af9d8953be
'}]
commit_message:
import "collections.abc" explicitly

The Collections Abstract Base Classes is moved to the
collections.abc module, which was earlier part of the
collections module[1].

The python3 reports a warning for the same-
DeprecationWarning: Using or importing the ABCs from
'collections' instead of from 'collections.abc' is
deprecated since Python 3.3, and in 3.10 it will stop working.

This patch updates to import collection.abc module explicitly.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/library/collections.abc.html

Change-Id: I18ba70140f9b2b53f2e97e70f64973af9d8953be

commit_message:
Add an audit watcher to check partition numbers

If you fail to properly cleanup during a part power increase, you may
have a bunch of diskfiles scattered throughout your cluster with the
wrong partition. Currently, the auditor doesn't do anything about them;
it'd be nice to at least log about the issue.

Change-Id: I24e7ceacd5e06674ec5389aa92bc4892c066518f

commit_message:
Copy existing IPv6 leases to generated lease file

Because the DHCP agent does not know the IAID (identity association
identifier) of assigned IPv6 addresses it's not possible to generate the
lease file including IPv6 leases. Because of this IPv6 addresses are
excluded when generating the lease file in case of DHCP agent restarts.
This causes DHCPv6 clients to fail to RENEW their lease and to go
through a full address discovery cycle with possible short connectivity
disruption.

This commit copies the existing IPv6 leaes from an already existing
lease file if present. While this does not allow for DHCP agent
failover, this is still better than just skipping the IPv6 addresses.

A lease file without the IPv6 addresses is still generated if an agent
is migrated to a different host.

This commit complements the fix implemented in
Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e which just skips the IPv6
leases as otherwise the lease file would be invalid and all leases would
be lost. It does not change the behavior for still valid IPv4 leases.

With this issue fixed an additional fix is required to not loose DHCPv6
leases when the agent restarts dnsmasq. Currently the DHCP agent
regenerates all configuration files on restart. This means that DHCPv6
leases are lost as they can't be regenerated. This changes the agent to
only delete the config files if the agent's ports are also removed.

Closes-Bug: #1722126
Related-Change: Ib1b2f284ab81f1c4af7b08b5257b45a3f6e79c3e

Change-Id: I40761b30563749251b9d74731bbe7a80a124da89
(cherry picked from commit 6bc1c00d66ced82dd142739790222e8408684696)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-04-07 17:51:19.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: ignored error state cache for new requests

A possibility exists where inspector *can* fail upon inspection if
the database connectivity was lost on a prior action. This is because
the last database transport is potentially bad and fails upon load for
the transaction. The cache can then end up with an "error" state entry,
which upon retrying can fail becasue it is already in error state

Because there really are no guarentees regarding database failures,
the best thing to do is to not trust the prior cache state if it is
in error and to reset it to starting upon new introspection requests.
This prevents operators from *having* to perform process restarts to
force all loads to be from the database unless they manage to have a
multi-inspector cluster and get another inspector node to inspect in
the mean time.

Change-Id: I04ae1d54028862642d043f3a8f3af99405863325
Story: 2008344
Task: 41246
'}, {'created': '2021-04-09 15:15:20.000000000', 'message': 'Ignored error state cache for new requests

the database connectivity was lost on a prior action. This is because
the last database transport is potentially bad and fails upon load for
the transaction. The cache can then end up with an "error" state entry,
which upon retrying can fail becasue it is already in error state

Because there really are no guarentees regarding database failures,
the best thing to do is to not trust the prior cache state if it is
in error and to reset it to starting upon new introspection requests.
This prevents operators from *having* to perform process restarts to
force all loads to be from the database unless they manage to have a
multi-inspector cluster and get another inspector node to inspect in
the mean time.

Change-Id: I04ae1d54028862642d043f3a8f3af99405863325
Story: 2008344
Task: 41246
Related: rhbz#1947147
'}, {'created': '2021-06-09 13:10:45.000000000', 'message': 'Ignored error state cache for new requests

the best thing to do is to not trust the prior cache state if it is
in error and to reset it to starting upon new introspection requests.
This prevents operators from *having* to perform process restarts to

commit_message:
Ignored error state cache for new requests

A possibility exists where inspector *can* fail upon inspection if
the database connectivity was lost on a prior action. This is because
the last database transport is potentially bad and fails upon load for
the transaction. The cache can then end up with an "error" state entry,
which upon retrying can fail becasue it is already in error state

Because there really are no guarentees regarding database failures,
the best thing to do is to not trust the prior cache state if it is
in error and to reset it to starting upon new introspection requests.
This prevents operators from *having* to perform process restarts to
force all loads to be from the database unless they manage to have a
multi-inspector cluster and get another inspector node to inspect in
the mean time.

Change-Id: I04ae1d54028862642d043f3a8f3af99405863325
Story: 2008344
Task: 41246
Related: rhbz#1947147

[{'created': '2021-07-01 17:39:19.000000000', 'message': 'Fix ipaddress issues in the infinidat driver

In python3.8.11 and python3.9.6, the behavior of the
ipaddress.ip_network.hosts() method changed. Now /32
addresses are returned by that method as a single
element list. This was apparently done as a bugfix [1]

Change-Id: Iab6d96351fa21131d834ccf07ffddd70555f25a7
Closes-Bug: #1934345
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue27683
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ipaddress issues in the infinidat driver

In python3.8.11 and python3.9.6, the behavior of the
ipaddress.ip_network.hosts() method changed. Now /32
addresses are returned by that method as a single
element list. This was apparently done as a bugfix [1]

Change-Id: Iab6d96351fa21131d834ccf07ffddd70555f25a7
Closes-Bug: #1934345
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
[1] https://bugs.python.org/issue27683

(6 comments)

SQLAlchemy 1.4 will improve performance on the "query construction and execution"  part of this, that is, the overhead of saying "query(a, b, c, d, e)" and getting that through to receiving result sets.     For the overhead of building up ~1000 full ORM objects from rows that have ~50 columns plus joinedload collections, that is likely not much improved, as that aspect of SQLAlchemy has been optimized quite a bit. 

To immediately reduce the columns being fetched without rewriting everything, the additional cols you dont need from these ORM objects can be more easily omitted from an ORM query using deferred column loading / load_only, see https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/loading_columns.html?highlight=deferred#load-only-and-wildcard-options .

That is, you could still load ORM model objects here and limit the columns fetched using a phrase like query.options(load_only("id", "version", "updated_at", ..)).

The other thing is that assuming "Traits" here are normally loaded using joined eager loading, you might want to try on the existing full ORM code the "selectinload" strategy instead, it is generally more efficient for related collections especially on MySQL as it does not use joins or subqueries, and will overall greatly reduce the amount of data coming over the wire: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/14/orm/loading_relationships.html#selectin-eager-loading.   If right now you have each Node with 50 cols each and then 10 joined rows for Traits, you are loading 500 redundant node cols over the wire, rather than just the 50 you need.  


besides that I have comments inline for the approach being taken here which is also perfectly fine.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-06-01 22:05:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14629, 'date': '2021-06-02 01:17:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> 
> There's at least one potential SQL injection vulnerability introduced here that IMO has to change, and otherwise I apologize but I would prefer if we could blame SQLAlchemy a little less here.   It makes my job harder when people don't trust the library and while I don't have a problem if developers want to roll their own, the rationale here should likely be put down as developer preference.

Hey Mike,

Sorry for coming off as blaming SQLAlchemy. The last few months have just been... exceedingly frustrating. I'll actually end up dropping the entire commit message and I'll try going back to the drawing board. Who knows, maybe that will be even faster! Just hopefully not slower like my frist half dozen couple attempts. 😭

I don't think it is necessarily developer preference. I think it is more finely nuanced then that, but I see your point. I don't think I'm ready to accept it, but your making a really valid point. I think it is hard for me because I've managed to record a startling performance improvement, but... we all have our different focuses and perceptions of what is important, and there is nothing wrong with that."}, {'account_id': 11816, 'date': '2021-06-18 15:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

hey there.

don't go back to the drawing board, you have code here that's doing what you want and it's performant, that is great.   enough time has been spent.   The message can be "it was most expedient to replace the SQLAlchemy ORM with the use of Core directly".    for the text() thing, yes, people see that kind of thing and they will note it as a SQL injection just for the appearance of it, if the code were later refactored or used in some other way, etc.   you can replace it like this:

    res = ro_client.execute(
         sql.select(NodeTrait.node_id, NodeTrait.trait, NodeTrait.version).
         where(NodeTrait.node_id.in_(node_ids))
    )

that's all I am suggesting.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-06-18 18:42:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14629, 'date': '2021-06-18 18:43:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-05-19 22:10:00.000000000', 'message': "Only return the requested fields

A major issue with sqlalchemy is the fact that whenever a model
is interacted with, all fields are returned by the SQL database.
All fields are then converted to objects. Rinse/repeat, but on a
table such as the nodes table with a large number of fields, this
creates an exceptional amount of un-necessary work.

To lay this out:
1) SQL call completes, cursor is returned server side relatively
   quickly.
2) SQLAlchemy uses the server side cursor and functionally
   downloads the entire table. If specific columns are requested,
   but the table level model is referenced, SQLAlchemy will
   actually do even more work in order to return complete objects.
3) SQLAlchemy generates and populates the objects for each field on
   the object model, which is then passed to Ironic's code.

Prior to this change, ironic's code, for any list of all nodes,
including when only a handfull of columns were requested or needed,
all nodes would be downloaded, transformed as above, then take the
entire object and pass it up through all the layers.

In this case, if a specific list of fields is selected, the code
will take a different path. The entire objects will not be populated
but the minimum necessary columns.

Story: 2008885
Task: 42434
Change-Id: Iac703d2a9b7b240a47477be8a64c7c33e28f692f
