commit_message:
Remove epel-release using yum/dnf

With [1] epel-next-release added as weak dep
to epel-release, so now epel-release cannot
be removed alone due to below error, so let's
used dnf/yum for removal as that will clean
the deps too.

epel-release = 8-11.el8 is needed by (installed)
epel-next-release-8-11.el8.noarch

[1] https://koji.mbox.centos.org/koji/buildinfo?buildID=18210

Change-Id: I893d63bf9ffa4b960ab76a54d76af5c58ef428a7

commit_message:
Export crash dumps when Ceph daemons crash

This change configures Ceph daemon pods so that
/var/lib/ceph/crash maps to a hostPath location that persists
when the pod restarts. This will allow for post-mortem examination
of crash dumps to attempt to understand why daemons have crashed.

Change-Id: I53277848f79a405b0809e0e3f19d90bbb80f3df8

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-24 06:59:32.000000000', 'message': "Remove FIP agent's gw port when L3 agent is deleted

Floating IP agent gateway ports are created for each external network
for each node where DVR L3 agent is running and where there is some FIP
from the ext_net.
But even, if L3 agent is removed (e.g. when scaling down the cluster),
such floating IP gateway port is never removed so it consumes IP address
from the external network.

With this patch when the DVR L3 agent is deleted, all such fip gateway
ports owned by that agent will be deleted.
When new L3 agent is created (registered in the DB), Neutron will check
if there are any floating IPs on that host and will recreate such FIP
gateway ports for it.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_dvr_db.py

Closes-Bug: #1891360
Change-Id: If6ef990baf039c556d7420962ac4c54608711f06
(cherry picked from commit 8cc7c0cf7a5196103b097fae67eccbd5dc3980ac)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove FIP agent's gw port when L3 agent is deleted

Floating IP agent gateway ports are created for each external network
for each node where DVR L3 agent is running and where there is some FIP
from the ext_net.
But even, if L3 agent is removed (e.g. when scaling down the cluster),
such floating IP gateway port is never removed so it consumes IP address
from the external network.

With this patch when the DVR L3 agent is deleted, all such fip gateway
ports owned by that agent will be deleted.
When new L3 agent is created (registered in the DB), Neutron will check
if there are any floating IPs on that host and will recreate such FIP
gateway ports for it.

Conflicts:
    neutron/tests/unit/db/test_l3_dvr_db.py

Closes-Bug: #1891360
Change-Id: If6ef990baf039c556d7420962ac4c54608711f06
(cherry picked from commit 8cc7c0cf7a5196103b097fae67eccbd5dc3980ac)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-07-01 14:46:13.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure py3 pkgs installed on series-upgrade

On series-upgrade the g-s-s stopped syncing due python packages required
by the sync file (that is run in the context of the unit, rather than
the charm) not being present.  I believe they may have been removed
during the series-upgrade when unused packages were removed.

This patch ensures that on both upgrade and series upgrade, all the
packages that are needed are installed.

Change-Id: I8dfa9b0111fa3f204364e2c0833595bf8b219a7c
Closes-Bug: #1934306
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure py3 pkgs installed on series-upgrade

On series-upgrade the g-s-s stopped syncing due python packages required
by the sync file (that is run in the context of the unit, rather than
the charm) not being present.  I believe they may have been removed
during the series-upgrade when unused packages were removed.

This patch ensures that on both upgrade and series upgrade, all the
packages that are needed are installed.

Change-Id: I8dfa9b0111fa3f204364e2c0833595bf8b219a7c
Closes-Bug: #1934306

Change-Id: I53892137eb65ecc9530bd3859c651b12ab228a58

commit_message:
CI: fix backups Ceph pool name

We configure Cinder to use a 'backups' pool by default, but in CI we
create a 'backup' pool in Ceph. This change fixes CI to use 'backups'.

Change-Id: I53892137eb65ecc9530bd3859c651b12ab228a58

commit_message:
Allow tuning timeouts for mysql pacemaker resource

This change introduces several timeout parameters so that users can
tune operation timeouts about mysql resource in pacemaker.

Change-Id: Ib1e0e687e2f8dd5dba53a37f6d4e5f149b933fd4

commit_message:
Default Heat images to container image prepare defaults

Use the defaults from container image prepare to set the default values
for the standalone and undercloud heat api and engine images. This will
allow the default upstream or downstream defaults from the right branch
to be used.

Additionally this patch splits out the ephemeral heat containers to a
special namespace and tag that we use in THT to setup the containers for
the overcloud deploy command on an undercloud.

related-bug: 1931995
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/796617
Change-Id: I55fb9816e2b0a54717938b7a094bde6780811305
Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Alex Schultz <aschultz@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 268f638f15305d4d59b9a008307611772cce35f1)

commit_message:
Use ephemeral Heat by default

Switches to use ephemeral Heat by default for all overcloud operations
and defaults enable_heat to False in undercloud.conf. Stack data will be
migrated to the ephemeral Heat model (to use the consistent working
directory) as part of the upgrade with the inclusion of the depends-on.

To improve the UX when using ephemeral Heat, "stack resource list" is
now run after "stack failures list" automaticaly in the case of Heat
stack failures.

Signed-off-by: James Slagle <jslagle@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I22b2ec530f8b888a94a88e1726792a8afef227ab
(cherry picked from commit 030e9f0b570e3ab119c68b7ab7e0220a09dd48a1)

commit_message:
Handle backward compatibility for Cliff 2.16.0 (stable/train)

In stable/train Cliff version is 2.16.0 which force us
to pin validations-libs or to handle backward compat directly
in the code.
For long term solution and to avoid tagging, pinning and complex
release management this review fix the compatibility with Cliff 2.16.0

Change-Id: I6dec4c154f088e8cc6450d5d9cf2f9b407fdefdc

commit_message:
Remove content-provider to decrease CI time

Since we only use 1 TripleO standalone job, we dont need
to run the content provided job, but only build containers
in the standalone job.

Removing the content-provider job will decrease significatively
the duration of the zuul runs

Change-Id: Iece25ad6b30c75af99654a78eb8663d6af76952f

commit_message:
tripleo-transfer: ability to customize files transfer options

There are use cases where it's useful to be able to explicitly
exclude files from a transfer request. For example when syncing galera
database, we don't want to copy coredumps, local galera state file...

Add the ability to explicitly include or exclude files by specifying
a list of files or wildcard-based patterns.

Also make the default transfer options configurable, to best suit
transfer use cases.

Related-Bug: #1925260

Change-Id: I1e88907db0bb26d52c92cb996eb56767e06b3874
(cherry picked from commit 6f75fd172326b010e680fc0bdda8d880e256a58e)

Legacy telemetry has been disabled by default and we
don't need these environments anymore.

commit_message:
Fix networking-l2gw location

Most part of this commit is similar to a gate change in stable/rocky
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/networking-odl/+/798298,
but the main goal is not to refer openstack/networking-l2gw in
the zuul configuration.

* Replace openstack/networking-l2gw reference with x/networking-l2gw
* tox_install_project.sh is adjusted to consume x/networking-l2gw
* Drop failing jobs as we do in stable/rocky
* Specify python2.7 as basepython in the pep8 tox env
  as python2.7 was the default python in Queens
* Cap bandit with <1.6.0 so that the job works with python2.7
* Run requirements-check on ubuntu-bionic.
  It seems required, otherwise the job fails.

Change-Id: Ifa58ef2012797ea1975aa435d7261c99fb5b6246

commit_message:
Fix pep8 check

With pylint >= 2.9.0 neutron-lib pep8 fails with following error:

neutron_lib/api/extensions.py:256:4: W0237: Parameter
'extended_attributes' has been renamed to 'attributes' in overridden
'APIExtensionDescriptor.update_attributes_map' method
(arguments-renamed)

Closes-Bug: #1934301
Change-Id: Ia3fb78cda862f730b51775fa48eec673d971c93b

commit_message:
Remove content-provider to decrease CI time

Since we only use 1 TripleO standalone job, we dont need
to run the content provided job, but only build containers
in the standalone job.

Removing the content-provider job will decrease significatively
the duration of the zuul runs

Change-Id: I7d6804b67fbf5b217a9cf68154b313d1e723afd9

commit_message:
Remove ocata from periodic job template of neutron and ceilometer

Neutron [1] and Ceilometer [2] projects stable/ocata moved to End of
Life. This patch removes stable/ocata from their periodic-stable-jobs-*
job template, as they are not needed and cannot run anymore.

[1] Ib0aa4d8cfa0856ca42adee2b755ba1610f10bdb8
[2] I30f8dd2cbf0a6d81098dee44c32cdf76a2475901

Change-Id: If130526b906bccb9a0f807bbbc8281041dfd04bc

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-30 15:19:54.000000000', 'message': "Add election_results to cycle data

The Jinja templates for formatting the election results expect an
'election_results' property to be loaded from the results yaml files to
generate election results.

There have been a few election cycles for PTLs now that have not needed
a election due to only having one candidate. In these cases, the yaml
files for the ptl results of those election cycles did not include the
empty 'election_results' property. This adds it to the missing data sets
to allow the docs job to pass.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I759b06a6b977299873ec8ab1f7e727d8b7071518
"}]
commit_message:
Add election_results to cycle data

The Jinja templates for formatting the election results expect an
'election_results' property to be loaded from the results yaml files to
generate election results.

There have been a few election cycles for PTLs now that have not needed
a election due to only having one candidate. In these cases, the yaml
files for the ptl results of those election cycles did not include the
empty 'election_results' property. This adds it to the missing data sets
to allow the docs job to pass.

Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I759b06a6b977299873ec8ab1f7e727d8b7071518

I have addressed the answers to the questions and done some moidications in the text... Please check them inline!'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 15:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

My concerns about failure if back ends don't support these is handled by the capability introduced in the last revision.

I'm still not quite there with respect to failures due to duplicate mount_point choices.  Ideally we'd have some way to detect duplicates at the API layer and fail synchronously but we don't know what back end the scheduler will choose at that point.
So that takes us to the idea would that internally the mount_point actually has the share uuid appended.  Users would only see and work with shortened, simple formats for mount_points (that's all they'd need to remember, and all that would be displayed to them) but these shortened forms are always in the context of a unique share so internally there would be no duplication.  I think that may be the drift of the review comments from Goutham on "deduplication" and your responses on that thread?'}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-24 18:55:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> My concerns about failure if back ends don't support these is handled by the capability introduced in the last revision.
> 
> I'm still not quite there with respect to failures due to duplicate mount_point choices.  Ideally we'd have some way to detect duplicates at the API layer and fail synchronously but we don't know what back end the scheduler will choose at that point.
> So that takes us to the idea would that internally the mount_point actually has the share uuid appended.  Users would only see and work with shortened, simple formats for mount_points (that's all they'd need to remember, and all that would be displayed to them) but these shortened forms are always in the context of a unique share so internally there would be no duplication.  I think that may be the drift of the review comments from Goutham on "deduplication" and your responses on that thread?

Oh, I get your point... The thing is: for DHSS=True, as Goutham mentioned, this will be a lot easier to validate and we can just query the share server shares before sending the request to the share driver... In the DHSS=False case, the way out I can think now is to try to look into the project shares', check the ones that are matching the host and validate if any of these is holding the same mount_path_name...

Still, the creation can fail, considering that other share having the same mount_path_name in another tenant could be created in the backend that is related to a single share server, and in this case, the failure would be raised by the share driver, and using this approach, there is not a way to prevent the failure before sending the request to the driver to create the share...

So in this scenario, there are two options for the driver:
1. Fail the request, considering that it tried to enable the custom export location but it couldn't handle it, due to duplication
2. As soon as it tries to configure the custom export location and it fails, log the error and if the other export locations are okay, make the operation successful...

I'm concerned about option 2 since it wouldn't make the share creation request fail, even though something the user explictly requested during the share creation won't be respected...'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-06-24 19:12:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 30002, 'date': '2021-06-24 19:34:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-06-24 20:13:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-24 20:29:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 20:52:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

With respect to the fail early (or rather, don't fail late) question, I'm suggesting that late failures because of duplicates can be avoided by using an internal representation of the mount point that doesn't allow for duplicates.  Different users (think DHSS=False where they are in different projects) may ask for the same memorable mount-point (e.g. 1.2.3.4:/exports/share1) but these will be for different shares and internally the mount-point will be 1.2.3.4:/exports/<share-uuid>/mountpoint or some such so that they are unique.  The simple mount points would be displayed to the users and accepted since they can be internally transformed to unique mount points because the share context and its uuid are available."}, {'account_id': 30002, 'date': '2021-06-24 21:16:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> With respect to the fail early (or rather, don't fail late) question, I'm suggesting that late failures because of duplicates can be avoided by using an internal representation of the mount point that doesn't allow for duplicates.  Different users (think DHSS=False where they are in different projects) may ask for the same memorable mount-point (e.g. 1.2.3.4:/exports/share1) but these will be for different shares and internally the mount-point will be 1.2.3.4:/exports/<share-uuid>/mountpoint or some such so that they are unique.  The simple mount points would be displayed to the users and accepted since they can be internally transformed to unique mount points because the share context and its uuid are available.

Hey Tom, how this would work from user's point of view? How/where this export location mapping will be made?"}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 21:23:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > Patch Set 2:

> > With respect to the fail early (or rather, don't fail late) question, I'm suggesting that late failures because of duplicates can be avoided by using an internal representation of the mount point that doesn't allow for duplicates.  Different users (think DHSS=False where they are in different projects) may ask for the same memorable mount-point (e.g. 1.2.3.4:/exports/share1) but these will be for different shares and internally the mount-point will be 1.2.3.4:/exports/<share-uuid>/mountpoint or some such so that they are unique.  The simple mount points would be displayed to the users and accepted since they can be internally transformed to unique mount points because the share context and its uuid are available.
> 
> Hey Tom, how this would work from user's point of view? How/where this export location mapping will be made?

It could be made in the API layer and the user would never see it.  User always works with simple mount_id and share.  Internally these are converted and de-converted in the api layer to unique mount_ids and back to the simple form.

I could be trippin though."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 22:09:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Thanks, Carlos.  The only remaining worry for me is that project names aren't unique except within a keystone domain: you can make a 'demo' project in domain1 and 'demo' in domain2.  Maybe the liklihood of this situation with DHSS=false and the same share server across both auth domains is small enough we can live with this possibility.  The user will get a late, asynchronous error in such cases.  But I'd like to see what others reviewers think."}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-27 13:54:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Thank you for revisiting, Tom... Please see answers inline'}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-27 13:56:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

commit_message:
Add a nonvoting functional job with RBAC defaults

This adds a new tox target called functional-py38-rbac which enables
the new secure RBAC policy defaults for all functional tests. To do
this, the functional tests needed a little bit of extra work to
actually set those, and a new non-voting job is added to run these
in CI.

Related to blueprint policy-refactor

Change-Id: Id376193521671bdb0ebc08ea8e563578bbaa541f

Just added another point but I'll let this one up to you."}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-05-17 02:19:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

>

thank you very much, Carlos Eduardo."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2021-05-17 05:43:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

Thanks haixin, makes sense.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 17:02:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I support this and the spec seems to cover the bases well.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 17:33:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thinking more about this, we need to talk about quotas and whether having shares still take space without consuming quota is something we really want.
I'm putting the vote as -1 for now just to ensure the discussion -- don't think we're ready to merge until we resolve that explicitly."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-24 17:48:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1
> 
> Thinking more about this, we need to talk about quotas and whether having shares still take space without consuming quota is something we really want.
> I'm putting the vote as -1 for now just to ensure the discussion -- don't think we're ready to merge until we resolve that explicitly.

If we implement this, then it may force current cloud administrators to change the way they do capacity planning and billing.  Users get six plus days of quota-less cold storage so real disk usage may be higher for the same number of reported shares than before.  That's the capacity planning issue.  From a billing standpoint, cloud admins must now decide whether to charge for shares in the trash bin or not, and either way whether users could game the system by moving shares in and out of the trash bin as needed.

These remarks are not intended to be fatal objections to the proposal, but I don't want us to implement this without thinking about such considerations."}, {'account_id': 30002, 'date': '2021-06-24 20:25:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I agree with Tom. If we let users (this proposal is not an admin-only operation) to soft-deleted shares and free their quotas, users will be able to deplete storage with a simple create + soft-delete script.
One solution would be to have 'recyble-bin' quotas
Or simply don't delete quotas when share are soft-deleted, only when they are actually deleted."}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-24 20:46:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: -Code-Review

> Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1
> 
> (3 comments)
> 
> I agree with Tom. If we let users (this proposal is not an admin-only operation) to soft-deleted shares and free their quotas, users will be able to deplete storage with a simple create + soft-delete script.
> One solution would be to have 'recyble-bin' quotas
> Or simply don't delete quotas when share are soft-deleted, only when they are actually deleted.

I agree with Tom and Douglas on this... I think releasing the quotas as soon as the shares are deleted should be okay...
In the other hand, having quotas for the recycle bin is not a bad idea, and it would allow people to query the configured quotas... It could also have entries to the absolute limits, so people would be able to see how what is the current consumed and available amount of resources..."}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-25 02:34:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(5 comments)

hi, everyone.
Thank you for your review.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-25 02:35:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 29632, 'date': '2021-06-25 20:26:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-26 14:34:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Thanks for taking my worries about quota-less "cold-storage" into account.  I think that will help cloud administrators do capacity planning.  I think there may still be billing headaches that this functionality would introduce though.

Consider a cloud administrator running Manila with Wallaby who bills customers using a program that lists the number of shares for each project.  That program now needs to be re-written to consider soft-deleted shares as well.  The cloud administrator must consider whether to charge for these at the same rate as non-deleted shares, or to charge less for these since they cannot be used.  If they charge less, then do they open themselves to abuse by users who use soft-deleted storage as "cold storage" by soft-deleting shares and then un-deleting them briefly every six and one half days before soft-deleting them again.

I'm not sure a cloud administrator who is happy on Wallaby without the soft-deletion feature will be happy that we added this new feature on Xena without a way for them to disable it if they don't want to deal with these billing complications.

My -1 at this point doesn't mean I'm dead set against this proposal, but rather that I think it still needs more consideration by the communnity before deciding to go ahead with it.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-28 02:20:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(3 comments)

> Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1
> 
> Thanks for taking my worries about quota-less "cold-storage" into account.  I think that will help cloud administrators do capacity planning.  I think there may still be billing headaches that this functionality would introduce though.
> 
> Consider a cloud administrator running Manila with Wallaby who bills customers using a program that lists the number of shares for each project.  That program now needs to be re-written to consider soft-deleted shares as well.  The cloud administrator must consider whether to charge for these at the same rate as non-deleted shares, or to charge less for these since they cannot be used.  If they charge less, then do they open themselves to abuse by users who use soft-deleted storage as "cold storage" by soft-deleting shares and then un-deleting them briefly every six and one half days before soft-deleting them again.
> 
> I'm not sure a cloud administrator who is happy on Wallaby without the soft-deletion feature will be happy that we added this new feature on Xena without a way for them to disable it if they don't want to deal with these billing complications.
> 
> My -1 at this point doesn't mean I'm dead set against this proposal, but rather that I think it still needs more consideration by the communnity before deciding to go ahead with it.

thanks for your review Carlos Eduardo and Tom Barron.

hi Tom, about the scenario you described,I don't think cloud administrators
need to struggle with charging, Because the Share List is not the only interface
to query the size and number of a user's shares, there is another CLI: manila quota-show
--tenant-id xxxx  --user-id xxxx --detail, this will tell cloud administrators
how many shares are currently being used by a particular user and how much capacity
is being used, Of course, the result of the query is include the shares in the
Recycle Bin. This interface shows the total usage directly, unlike the Share List
interface, which returns the results and then adds them up. Therefore, I believe
that the billing program uses the quota interface rather than the share list interface.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-28 02:21:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-28 02:24:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

That program now needs to be re-written to consider soft-deleted shares as well.  The cloud administrator must consider whether to charge for these at the same rate as non-deleted shares, or to charge less for these since they cannot be used.  If they charge less, then do they open themselves to abuse by users who use soft-deleted storage as "cold storage" by soft-deleting shares and then un-deleting them briefly every six and one half days before soft-deleting them again.
> > 
> > I'm not sure a cloud administrator who is happy on Wallaby without the soft-deletion feature will be happy that we added this new feature on Xena without a way for them to disable it if they don't want to deal with these billing complications.
> > 
> > My -1 at this point doesn't mean I'm dead set against this proposal, but rather that I think it still needs more consideration by the communnity before deciding to go ahead with it.
>

> --tenant-id xxxx  --user-id xxxx --detail, this will tell cloud administrators
> how many shares are currently being used by a particular user and how much capacity
> is being used, Of course, the result of the query is include the shares in the
> Recycle Bin. This interface shows the total usage directly, unlike the Share List
> interface, which returns the results and then adds them up. Therefore, I believe
> that the billing program uses the quota interface rather than the share list interface.

We could even add a configuration item to control whether Manila turns on the Recycle Bin or not'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-06-28 20:58:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(15 comments)

Thank you for this work, Haixin. Please take a look at the comments inline'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-29 02:20:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-29 02:42:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-29 02:43:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(15 comments)

hi, Goutham Pacha Ravi
thanks for your review.'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-29 14:18:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)

> I don't think cloud administrators
> need to struggle with charging, Because the Share List is not the only interface
> to query the size and number of a user's shares, there is another CLI: manila quota-show
> --tenant-id xxxx  --user-id xxxx --detail, this will tell cloud administrators
> how many shares are currently being used by a particular user and how much capacity
> is being used, Of course, the result of the query is include the shares in the
> Recycle Bin. This interface shows the total usage directly, unlike the Share List
> interface, which returns the results and then adds them up. Therefore, I believe
> that the billing program uses the quota interface rather than the share list interface.

Sure, but my point is that all cloud adminstrators will need to adapt their billing systems for this new feature, whether they actually want it or not.

This is a  nice feature for human users who may make mistakes. It gives them an easy way to correct them.  But if I run a cloud that is mostly used by automated programs instead of humans then this feature isn't going to be valuable to me -- I have to change the way I bill and make sure somehow that this feature isn't abused by those who cleverly use soft deleted shares as a form of cold storage.

You mentioned the possibility of making this new feature optional.  I'm curious what other reviewers think."}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-06-29 21:19:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> > I don't think cloud administrators
> > need to struggle with charging, Because the Share List is not the only interface
> > to query the size and number of a user's shares, there is another CLI: manila quota-show
> > --tenant-id xxxx  --user-id xxxx --detail, this will tell cloud administrators
> > how many shares are currently being used by a particular user and how much capacity
> > is being used, Of course, the result of the query is include the shares in the
> > Recycle Bin. This interface shows the total usage directly, unlike the Share List
> > interface, which returns the results and then adds them up. Therefore, I believe
> > that the billing program uses the quota interface rather than the share list interface.
> 
> Sure, but my point is that all cloud adminstrators will need to adapt their billing systems for this new feature, whether they actually want it or not.

Do we think cloud administrators want to bill someone lesser if their shares are soft-deleted? No quota or consumption reduction will occur until the shares are deleted. I see this feature as just hiding the shares from the list command and deferring deletion, and nothing else - so the impact on deployers may not show until they decide to provide differential value for this "recycle bin".

> 
> This is a  nice feature for human users who may make mistakes. It gives them an easy way to correct them.  But if I run a cloud that is mostly used by automated programs instead of humans then this feature isn't going to be valuable to me -- I have to change the way I bill and make sure somehow that this feature isn't abused by those who cleverly use soft deleted shares as a form of cold storage.
> 
> You mentioned the possibility of making this new feature optional.  I'm curious what other reviewers think.

Hmm, the /action API being introduced will be brand new, there will be an RBAC policy for using it; so if cloud administrators want to prevent this, they can manipulate the policy. We can document this'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2021-06-29 21:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2021-06-29 22:22:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2

I'd personally prefer default policy with this turned off so that existing cloud admins who don't want the feature or don't want to have to count shares for billing differently or who don't want to think about how they will charge for soft-deleted shares don't have to do anything.  But I'm not dug in, and it seems mine is a minority opinion.  Let's go ahead with this but make sure to document the upgrade implications for such operators so they can take appropriate action."}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-30 02:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I see this feature as just hiding the shares from the list command and deferring deletion, and nothing else - so the impact on deployers may not show until they decide to provide differential value for this "recycle bin".

But if I run a cloud that is mostly used by automated programs instead of humans then this feature isn't going to be valuable to me -- I have to change the way I bill and make sure somehow that this feature isn't abused by those who cleverly use soft deleted shares as a form of cold storage.

i agree with Goutham Pacha Ravi, cloud administrators not have to adapt their billing systems for this new feature, because no quota or consumption reduction after share deleted to recycle bin, the cloud administrator can charge the same for shares in the Recycle Bin. Unless they actively adjust their pricing strategy for the recycling station.'}, {'account_id': 30407, 'date': '2021-06-30 02:25:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

commit_message:
Manila share support Recycle Bin

Add support share Recycle Bin, the end user can soft delete
share to Recycle Bin, and can restore the share within 7 dyas,
otherwise the share will be deleted automatically.

Partially-Implements: blueprint manila-share-support-recycle-bin

Change-Id: I9359387267aa617f07e977e30da11efaead2b171

commit_message:
TripleO: Reduce tempest test scope

This change reduces scope of tempest tests in tripleo job, so that we
run only subset of test cases used in TripleO repos.

Change-Id: Idecb41c3cd78e6cc87f324f41ed77b981c3025ce
(cherry picked from commit a73d22babd41a67510cea48747fe95b3330ec1bc)
(cherry picked from commit 5d581f04389cda0ece093fcc599e8e4b1d13cd6e)

commit_message:
Improve support for tags

Previously we had defined some tags but there wasn't any way to make use of them(like galera_server-backups), this change improves tag support

Change-Id: Ib8fd1aca7aa85d7fe17376ca7f6629b1db0dac88

commit_message:
Skip port create if MAC is blank

During redifsh inspect, skip the creation of ports for
any nics that are reported without a MAC address.

Story: #2009016
Task: #42736
Change-Id: I1815ebaf7ed9882d8c61a0741fb605dff2db7efb

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-29 18:15:55.000000000', 'message': "Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

When the support to load the default bootloader configuration was
backported to stable train, I modified it to pass python2 unit tests
as well as ultimately attempt to be compatible.

It might have actually worked! What did not work, was that same file
open format on Python3 in actual production cases where unicode bytes
were being loaded from a file. This is because we couldn't explicitly
declare the utf-16 encoding necessary on the file open, which resulted
in Python3 thinking it was loading a non-uncode file, and promtply
failing when attempting.

Since python2 is past it's End of Support, and any compatability we try
and keep is because we're nice people, I'm retcon'ing the compatability
in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic-python-agent/+/796031
in preference for python3 functionality, and issuing a nice warning
message saying to upgrade Python.

This issue was identified in RHOSP testing with python 3.6, with
partition images where the deployment would fail with reporting
that the ascii codec could not decode 0xFF which indicates that the
contents are being handled as something other than utf-16, and it
is hitting a constraint in string handling in Python where ascii and
utf-8 character code points are expected to always be <0xFF.

rhbz#1977417

Change-Id: I08664c2b3900448633837e40098a0ff9f0bd65f7
"}, {'created': '2021-06-29 18:53:44.000000000', 'message': "Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

"}, {'created': '2021-06-30 15:11:39.000000000', 'message': 'Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

When the support to load the default bootloader configuration was
backported to stable train, I modified it to pass python2 unit tests
as well as ultimately attempt to be compatible.

It might have actually worked! What did not work for Python3 when the
UTF-16 codepoint delimiter file was encountered in a production case.
This passed CI originally just fine, however Ubuntu images do not have
the delimiter codepoint, where as RHEL images *do* have a UTF-16
delimiter at the start of the file.

On python3, with the python2 compatible code, the file was being opened
as ascii or UTF-8, which we know as the same rule applies for both. All
code points must be <0xFF. This resulted in the file open itself to fail,
as encoding support differs between Python2 and Python3.

What this patch does now is separately handle the case of if python2,
to use the new preview python3 io subsystem previewed in python2 to
open the file properly, and present the UTF-16 encoded results.

This issue was identified in RHOSP testing with python 3.6, with
partition images where the deployment would fail with reporting
that the ascii codec could not decode 0xFF which indicates that the
contents are being handled as something other than utf-16, and it
is hitting a constraint in string handling in Python where ascii and
utf-8 character code points are expected to always be <0xFF.

Story: 2009020

rhbz#1977417

commit_message:
Train only - Fix py3 support for bootloader default config load

When the support to load the default bootloader configuration was
backported to stable train, I modified it to pass python2 unit tests
as well as ultimately attempt to be compatible.

It might have actually worked! What did not work for Python3 when the
UTF-16 codepoint delimiter file was encountered in a production case.
This passed CI originally just fine, however Ubuntu images do not have
the delimiter codepoint, where as RHEL images *do* have a UTF-16
delimiter at the start of the file.

On python3, with the python2 compatible code, the file was being opened
as ascii or UTF-8, which we know as the same rule applies for both. All
code points must be <0xFF. This resulted in the file open itself to fail,
as encoding support differs between Python2 and Python3.

What this patch does now is separately handle the case of if python2,
to use the new preview python3 io subsystem previewed in python2 to
open the file properly, and present the UTF-16 encoded results.

This issue was identified in RHOSP testing with python 3.6, with
partition images where the deployment would fail with reporting
that the ascii codec could not decode 0xFF which indicates that the
contents are being handled as something other than utf-16, and it
is hitting a constraint in string handling in Python where ascii and
utf-8 character code points are expected to always be <0xFF.

Story: 2009020
Task: 42742
rhbz#1977417

Change-Id: I08664c2b3900448633837e40098a0ff9f0bd65f7

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I430301474e2294eb6f2d71fc521c73d23c6f8a55

commit_message:
Remove content-provider to decrease CI time

Since we only use 1 TripleO standalone job, we dont need
to run the content provided job, but only build containers
in the standalone job.

Removing the content-provider job will decrease significatively
the duration of the zuul runs

Change-Id: Ie13c85f8d80e17077d1a5b591a171248ab0eed28

Improvements needed in followup patch:

commit_message:
Use default policies in our tests

Made changes to use default policies in our unit and functional tests
rather than referring it from glance/tests/etc/policy.yaml file. Existing
function 'set_policy_rules' can be used to test custom policy rules in
functional testing.

Improvements needed in followup patch:
1. Property protection related unit tests still reads the special policy
from the policy.yaml file, need to make provision to override it instead.

2. Need to remove 'set_policy' function which actually responsible for
above behavior.

Related to blueprint policy-refactor
Change-Id: I0de9b9f9a7de499574101e3366ced730b0cb5fd1

commit_message:
Ensure backward compatibility with SQLAlchemy<1.4

In Ib6e3ed40dc8b075c3cecb967b7417097e3cab60d, a breaking change was
introduced to suppose SQLAlchemy 1.4.x but this PS ensures backward
compatibility with 1.3.x.

Change-Id: I73ef4f99f02abc8b1083860f34a8a8e084ad96fd

commit_message:
Do not test detail of oslo::cors

This change makes unit test cases for ironic::cors and
ironic::inspector::cors, so that these tests do not test behavir of
oslo::cors but how oslo::cors resource type is called by ironic::cors
and ironic::inspector::cors.

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic64800c031d61718ce4ea710c42669a081ebf107

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I5986087281694580acc3c19feed461b5949f7001

commit_message:

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/wallaby.

automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/wallaby.

commit_message:
Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().

[1] https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

Closes-Bug: #1933985
Change-Id: I8a318200752181defaf5ca4318d1e52f403f82be

[{'created': '2021-06-18 11:17:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add import system configuration method

set_virtual_boot_device is also using the import system configuration
action, but its usage is very specific, with retries and rebooting. To
keep it simple, this adds import_system_configuration, which is
asynchronous and returns a TaskMonitor.

Additionally, this changes the case of the header field names used by
the asynchronous.http_call method to make them work with unit tests.
While the requests package can handle real header field names case-
insensitively, when they are mocked in unit tests, case needs to match.

Story: 2003594
Task: 41576
Change-Id: I3b5e620e7b1939a029bd59b4578c0f52c8789598
(cherry picked from commit 1020e805d368684080660f10a5ee207d119c2b07)

commit_message:
Add import system configuration method

set_virtual_boot_device is also using the import system configuration
action, but its usage is very specific, with retries and rebooting. To
keep it simple, this adds import_system_configuration, which is
asynchronous and returns a TaskMonitor.

Additionally, this changes the case of the header field names used by
the asynchronous.http_call method to make them work with unit tests.
While the requests package can handle real header field names case-
insensitively, when they are mocked in unit tests, case needs to match.

Story: 2003594
Task: 41576
Change-Id: I3b5e620e7b1939a029bd59b4578c0f52c8789598
(cherry picked from commit 1020e805d368684080660f10a5ee207d119c2b07)

commit_message:
Add resources to put iDRAC in known good state

This change adds the iDRACCardService, JobCollection, JobService, and
LCService resources. Those offer actions to reset the iDRAC, get jobs,
delete jobs, and check if iDRAC is ready.

Change-Id: I29ce49c0865a610f2fb10f5072893bbf51b47303
Story: 2007617
Task: 40985
(cherry picked from commit 910d573c30ac2b090f8b0781233aa59bcfae5fdf)

commit_message:
Add volume_size_extend opt for volume tests

Volume tests had hardcoded value (1) in case they were creating
a second volume with a different size than the first one
(CONF.volume.volume_size). This is a problem for systems which
have a chunk size other than 1. The patch is adding a new opt
CONF.volume.volume_size_extend which allows customization of an
extended volume size.

Closes-Bug: 1917299
Change-Id: Ic8ae486224cd2a470f4f9bbad62d4d6715cc63ac

commit_message:
Change scale-down example with compute instead of controller

Since scaling down controllers was never supported, it might be a better
to use computes as example to prevent people from scaling down
controllers.

Change-Id: Id1508dbfa46292581bd20e15e79370b584183322

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> I have a few more deprecated things that I'd like to remove in oslo.db. I wonder if it would make sense to revert the deprecated option bindings patch, release a 9.x patch, and then reapply it with the additional changes and cut a 10.0.0 release? If so, I can propose the revert and reapply. If not, consider me +1 on this.

The question is more are you in rush?

Concerning myself I do not particularly need a new version quickly. You asked me if we could  release oslo.db ASAP after the merge of [1], so this is the reason of this patch. If you are not too much in rush to allow us to revert things as you suggested, then I agree that it would be worth to bring all the non backward compat changes together through a single major version. 

I -W this patch for now to allow you to reply. I let you handle the needed reverts and reapply them. Let me know if you need reviews and then I'll process them with an high priority.

Anyway, tags are cheaps so we could release a new major version again.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.db/commit/f3bdd4d4220a884e4752ce6b61c2605bfd72f2fb"}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-06-30 09:22:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1 -Workflow

So, Stephen and I decided to continue with this current version.

We will release another major version later to land the other deprecated/removed stuffs'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2021-06-30 09:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Only +1 to reflect my oslo caps and let the other release core members validate these changes'}, {'account_id': 17685, 'date': '2021-06-30 14:16:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

LGTM:
* major version bump is explained and looks OK (shouldn't reno show the same major version bump?)
* uploaded/approved by release liaison
* no issues found in test job logs"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2021-07-01 12:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Release oslo's independent deliverables

First release of etcd3gw under the openstack umbrella, support of
python 2 has been dropped so this is why I released a major version.
However I don't know how far we could consider etcd3gw as stable.

Proposing a new minor version of oslo.reports, oslo.log, and
oslo.rootwrap as py2 stuffs (conditions, six, etc...) have been cleaned.

Change-Id: Ie08cda2ed6285c9ce506432cb516161a85b49076

commit_message:
Unskip test_allocate_ips_are_from_correct_subnet test

This test was skipped due to bug in Neutron with [1] and [2].

Now it is properly skipped by neutron-tempest-plugin when required API
extension isn't available [3]. It should also be running fine when [2]
will be merged.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/+/797320
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/openstack-tempest-skiplist/+/798068
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin/+/797594
[4] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/797595

Closes-Bug: #1933115

Change-Id: I54ee3fcf48f20703d0c43a200354002c693e6bd9

commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update this at
each new cycle.

Wallaby support officially the following runtimes [1]:
- Python 3.6
- Python 3.8

During Victoria Python 3.7 was used as the default runtime [2] however this
version isn't longer officially supported.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/wallaby.html#python-runtimes-for-wallaby
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/victoria.html#python-runtimes-for-victoria

Change-Id: Id4b5cb679c60fda4132a10f684ed5128c0965230

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-30 15:10:08.000000000', 'message': "relinker: don't bother checking for previous tombstone links

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

Change-Id: Iae4ae0f0e3cf9a5de4219643b12af785b69bce20
"}]
commit_message:
relinker: don't bother checking for previous tombstone links

Since [1] the relinker had special case handling for EEXIST errors
caused by a different inode tombstone already existing in the next
partition power location: the relinker would check to see if the
existing next part power tombstone linked to a tombstone in a previous
part power (i.e. < current part power) location, and if so tolerate
the EEXIST.

This special case handling is no longer necessary because the relinker
will now tolerate an EEXIST when linking a tombstone provided the two
files have the same timestamp. There is therefore no need to search
previous part power locations for a tombstone that does link with the
next part power location.

The link_check_limit is no longer used but the --link-check-limit
command line option is still allowed (although ignored) for backwards
compatibility.

[1] Related-Change-Id: If9beb9efabdad64e81d92708f862146d5fafb16c

Change-Id: Iae4ae0f0e3cf9a5de4219643b12af785b69bce20

commit_message:
Drop warnings enable filter

[1] Enabled warnings without specifying category,
leading to all sort of warnings enabled, this patch
drops it and let it to consumers to enable warnings
types which they are interested in.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.utils/+/790429

Closes-Bug: #1934098
Change-Id: I822138c18e0932e8f7e3dc62267f167876c962ae

commit_message:
baremetal: Don't start Docker after install on Debian/Ubuntu

docker-ce on Debian/Ubuntu gets started just after installation, before
baremetal role configures daemon.json - which results in iptables rules
being implemented - but not removed on docker engine restart.

Closes-Bug: #1923203

Change-Id: Ib1faa092e0b8f0668d1752490a34d0c2165d58d2
(cherry picked from commit bc96179195de171a693b83405a472dddda596bff)

commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/wallaby

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/wallaby branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ie798cb4868eeb58c70a95cd9c53926c9ba270ffe

commit_message:
Replace deprecated with_lockmode with with_for_update

The Query.with_lockmode() method is deprecated since version 0.9.0
and will be removed in a future release. [1]
This patch replaces it with Query.with_for_update().
The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Also use upper-constraints in doc build to avoid issues in pdf build.

[1]
https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.with_lockmode

Closes-Bug: #1933226
Change-Id: I0ad514da647bb08790259fd27e56a41f6dbbbaa0
(cherry picked from commit 9ca44fa3ab16ba99c65b75c7fa2fde3b2c160b1d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-03-17 09:36:42.000000000', 'message': 'magnum: Add CA certificate configuration for internal TLS

Magnum has various sections in its configuration file for OpenStack
clients. When internal TLS is enabled, these may need a CA certificate
to be specified.

This change adds a CA certificate configuration, based on
openstack_cacert, for all clients using internal endpoints.

Note: we are explicitly not adding the configuration for the
[magnum_client] ca_file and [drivers] openstack_ca_file options, since
these use the public endpoint by default. These options may be
provided via custom configuration if necessary.

Change-Id: Ie59b3777c0a2c142b580addd67e279bc4b2f2c90
Co-Authored-By: Kyle Dean
Closes-Bug: #1919389
'}, {'created': '2021-03-24 10:13:13.000000000', 'message': 'magnum: Add CA certificate configuration for internal TLS

commit_message:
magnum: Add CA certificate configuration for internal TLS

Magnum has various sections in its configuration file for OpenStack
clients. When internal TLS is enabled, these may need a CA certificate
to be specified.

This change adds a CA certificate configuration, based on
openstack_cacert, for all clients using internal endpoints.

Note: we are explicitly not adding the configuration for the
[magnum_client] ca_file and [drivers] openstack_ca_file options, since
these use the public endpoint by default. These options may be
provided via custom configuration if necessary.

Change-Id: Ie59b3777c0a2c142b580addd67e279bc4b2f2c90
Co-Authored-By: Kyle Dean
Closes-Bug: #1919389

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-17 13:00:55.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid unhandled exceptions during connecting to iSCSI portals

Currently we don't properly catch some possible exceptions during
connectiing to iSCSI portals, like failures in "iscsiadm -m session".
Because of this _connect_vol threads can abort unexpectedly in some
failure patterns, and this abort causes hung in subsequent steps
waiting for results from _connct_vol threads.

This change ensures that any exceptions during connecting to iSCSI
portals are handled in the _connect_vol method corectly, to avoid
unexpected abort without updating thread results.

Conflicts:
        os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test_iscsi.py

Closes-Bug: #1915678
Change-Id: I0278c502806b99f8ec65cb146e3852e43031e9b8
(cherry picked from commit 4478433550ddab970f106636a4ba5fbba82c5e39)
(cherry picked from commit 57c8f4334c0e58b151f449f3316bb9e1c8ed6da4)
(cherry picked from commit c336cb76b318f987d43ff908a5b7c9d40b5c4dd6)
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid unhandled exceptions during connecting to iSCSI portals

Currently we don't properly catch some possible exceptions during
connectiing to iSCSI portals, like failures in "iscsiadm -m session".
Because of this _connect_vol threads can abort unexpectedly in some
failure patterns, and this abort causes hung in subsequent steps
waiting for results from _connct_vol threads.

This change ensures that any exceptions during connecting to iSCSI
portals are handled in the _connect_vol method corectly, to avoid
unexpected abort without updating thread results.

Conflicts:
        os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test_iscsi.py

Closes-Bug: #1915678
Change-Id: I0278c502806b99f8ec65cb146e3852e43031e9b8
(cherry picked from commit 4478433550ddab970f106636a4ba5fbba82c5e39)
(cherry picked from commit 57c8f4334c0e58b151f449f3316bb9e1c8ed6da4)
(cherry picked from commit c336cb76b318f987d43ff908a5b7c9d40b5c4dd6)

commit_message:
Use py3 as the default runtime for tox

Moving on py3 as the default runtime for tox to avoid to update
this at each new cycle.

Change-Id: I00108fb70f077eeda092c9124f37df51860df370

commit_message:
Fix broken testcase 'test_create_continuous_audit_with_wrong_interval'

The 'faultstring' was been modified to 'Exactly 5 or 6 columns has to be
specified for iterator expression', so adds one space between "iterator"
and "expression" for 'expected_error_msg'.

Closes-Bug: #1933708
Change-Id: I23893376a295d7919ff78a390e06e9b7422098c8

[{'created': '2021-04-27 06:57:43.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: Ide4d650a78829a6bc16d86b620e6b3fbed0bba06

commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: Ide4d650a78829a6bc16d86b620e6b3fbed0bba06

If guestarch in PPC/PPC64/PPCLE/PPC64LE/S390/S390X/AARCH64
and virt_type in qemu/kvm, the bus of cdrom is scsi. In some scsi instances,
cdrom_device occupied the unit after disk, If attach a new disk to the
instance, raise libvirtError: id duplicate. This patch fix it, returns the max
disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller

Change-Id: I86e78781e64084e569759642f782ff24f120c7d5
'}]
commit_message:
Returns the max disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller

If guestarch in PPC/PPC64/PPCLE/PPC64LE/S390/S390X/AARCH64
and virt_type in qemu/kvm, the bus of cdrom is scsi. In some scsi instances,
cdrom_device occupied the unit after disk, If attach a new disk to the
instance, raise libvirtError: id duplicate. This patch fix it, returns the max
disk/cdrom unit used by scsi controller

Change-Id: I86e78781e64084e569759642f782ff24f120c7d5

subject: setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores
messages: [{'account_id': 32326, 'date': '2021-05-04 09:01:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2021-07-01 08:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-05-04 09:01:27.000000000', 'message': "setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I0573f72eb92ddda5392dbf78260a18b17a8d75af
"}]
commit_message:
setup.cfg: Replace dashes with underscores

Setuptools v54.1.0 introduces a warning that the use of dash-separated
options in 'setup.cfg' will not be supported in a future version [1].
Get ahead of the issue by replacing the dashes with underscores. Without
this, we see 'UserWarning' messages like the following on new enough
versions of setuptools:

  UserWarning: Usage of dash-separated 'description-file' will not be
  supported in future versions. Please use the underscore name
  'description_file' instead

[1] https://github.com/pypa/setuptools/commit/a2e9ae4cb

Change-Id: I0573f72eb92ddda5392dbf78260a18b17a8d75af

commit_message:
Dropping lower constraints testing

We facing errors related to the new pip resolver, this
topic was discussed on the ML and QA team proposed to
to test lower-constraints [1].

I propose to drop this test because the complexity and recurring pain needed
to maintain that now exceeds the benefits provided by this mechanismes.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-December/019390.html

Change-Id: I9308030b0a16f9a7e085b3e64230cd92dda6ad83
(cherry picked from commit 427afe1f75665592c53b8597d46b9e25078627fa)

commit_message:
Test bundles for focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby

These are the test bundles (and any associated changes) for
focal-wallaby and hirsute-wallaby support.

hisute-wallaby test is disabled (moved to dev) due to [1] as bundle may
reference a reactive charm.

[1] https://github.com/juju-solutions/layer-basic/issues/194

Sync charm-helpers

Also pin prometheus2 charm in bundles to focal series as it does not
support groovy or hirsute.

Change-Id: I75602720f8e30be647aa8a1227d565c692ff8170
Co-authored-by: Aurelien Lourot <aurelien.lourot@canonical.com>

subject: Revert "Add neutron to stable upper-constraints"
messages:
[{'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-06-30 20:09:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2021-06-30 21:29:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not sure if we really can do this now. There are projects that use neutron as a library. For stable branches, we had run into issues in the past where some of these stable branches started breaking because they were unknowingly pulling in a neutron a few releases newer than what they had shipped with. The fix for that was to start adding neutron to stable constraints.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2021-06-30 21:41:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

as sean stated (and I mentioned in channel), the right way to this would be to cut many new releases in stable branches for you, which would suck.  I see you have reviews in place to exclude neutron from constraints, so that may be the way forward.'}, {'account_id': 28619, 'date': '2021-07-01 07:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-30 20:09:48.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Add neutron to stable upper-constraints"

This reverts commit 1c51379ed4dd3bbe97601c4b8eae9d058b134cb0.

Reason for revert: Neutron is being used also by other projects (like deployment ones) that need to comply with u-c and at the same time need to install specific service versions (with SHAs).
New pip resolver does not allow to have specific SHAs in constraints and thus it needs to be put into requirements, which results in conflict and being unable to install neutron and use u-c at the same time.

Change-Id: I16b30dcce2db84351460cc2c362a42a0b8532b79
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add neutron to stable upper-constraints"

This reverts commit 1c51379ed4dd3bbe97601c4b8eae9d058b134cb0.

Reason for revert: Neutron is being used also by other projects (like deployment ones) that need to comply with u-c and at the same time need to install specific service versions (with SHAs).
New pip resolver does not allow to have specific SHAs in constraints and thus it needs to be put into requirements, which results in conflict and being unable to install neutron and use u-c at the same time.

Change-Id: I16b30dcce2db84351460cc2c362a42a0b8532b79

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-06-09 17:47:41.000000000', 'message': "Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)
"}, {'created': '2021-06-30 06:59:00.000000000', 'message': "Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Conflicts: neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/impl_idl_ovn.py

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)
"}]
commit_message:
Use TCP keepalives for ovsdb connections

When failing over OVN DB servers from one server to another, the
server which originally hosted the VIP doesn't notice the connection
is gone and doesn't reconnect. Ultimately, this is something that
needs to be fixed in python-ovs, but setting the SO_KEEPALIVE socket
option avoids the issue. This also has the benefit that the client
doesn't need to send 'echo' requests, which can time out on an
overloaded ovsdb-server, which causes a disconnection which then
adds even more load on the ovsdb-server as it has to send the entire
db contents over the wire after the connection.

Conflicts: neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/impl_idl_ovn.py

Closes-Bug: #1930926
Change-Id: Ie0205785cab307c132fbe409588739685cade7c0
(cherry picked from commit 65cce351d74a9a637fdb2a9d5e0e63445dda9ea9)

commit_message:
Add build for ansible collections in build-test

Add building for 3 other ansible collections we use in TripleO:
  - ansible-collections/community.general
  - ansible-collections/ansible.posix
  - ansible-collections/ansible.netcommon

Change-Id: I6fe6a11d2121228aef480f4bd564fca422978566

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-05-13 15:48:48.000000000', 'message': 'Use ansible_facts to reference facts

Change-Id: I7e9d5c9b8b9164d4aee3abb4e37c8f28d98ff5d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements
'}, {'created': '2021-05-13 15:56:07.000000000', 'message': 'Use ansible_facts to reference facts

By default, Ansible injects a variable for every fact, prefixed with
ansible_. This can result in a large number of variables for each host,
which at scale can incur a performance penalty. Ansible provides a
configuration option [0] that can be set to False to prevent this
injection of facts. In this case, facts should be referenced via
ansible_facts.<fact>.

This change updates all references to Ansible facts within Kolla Ansible
from using individual fact variables to using the items in the
ansible_facts dictionary. This allows users to disable fact variable
injection in their Ansible configuration, which may provide some
performance improvement.

This change disables fact variable injection in the ansible
configuration used in CI, to catch any attempts to use the injected
variables.

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/config.html#inject-facts-as-vars

Change-Id: I7e9d5c9b8b9164d4aee3abb4e37c8f28d98ff5d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

This change disables fact variable injection in the ansible
configuration used in CI, to catch any attempts to use the injected
variables.

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/config.html#inject-facts-as-vars

Change-Id: I7e9d5c9b8b9164d4aee3abb4e37c8f28d98ff5d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements
'}]
commit_message:
Use ansible_facts to reference facts

By default, Ansible injects a variable for every fact, prefixed with
ansible_. This can result in a large number of variables for each host,
which at scale can incur a performance penalty. Ansible provides a
configuration option [0] that can be set to False to prevent this
injection of facts. In this case, facts should be referenced via
ansible_facts.<fact>.

This change updates all references to Ansible facts within Kolla Ansible
from using individual fact variables to using the items in the
ansible_facts dictionary. This allows users to disable fact variable
injection in their Ansible configuration, which may provide some
performance improvement.

This change disables fact variable injection in the ansible
configuration used in CI, to catch any attempts to use the injected
variables.

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/reference_appendices/config.html#inject-facts-as-vars

Change-Id: I7e9d5c9b8b9164d4aee3abb4e37c8f28d98ff5d1
Partially-Implements: blueprint performance-improvements

Open cinderlib for xena development

branch has just been cut, so transition master to xena development.

commit_message:
Add image_count_total quota enforcement

This makes us enforce a quota on the total number of (non-deleted)
images owned by a user.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I8af124d9307263cd8289d0701fb9a745d13b1d56

commit_message:
Add user_get_image_count() to DB API

This adds an efficient query method for getting a count of a user's
non-deleted images. It can be used by subsequent patches to enforce
the image count quota.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I4d6e071b8d48862032f36c80ee19632a3fe85009

commit_message:
Add image_stage_total quota enforcement

This makes us enforce a quota on the amount of data a user has in
staging.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: I3cca4e589adc0aec138e5933c311aefd69ccee51

commit_message:
Add user_get_staging_usage() to DB API

This adds a method that counts the sizes of images that are in the
process of doing an import, indicating that they are using staging
storage resources. We gather images that are in obvious states of
being created via import, as well as any images that appear to be
active but in the middle of a copy, since those could be using staging
resources as well.

This is somewhat mirrored from user_get_storage_usage(). Since there
was no test for that method, this adds a test case for both that and
the new method.

Partially-implements: blueprint glance-unified-quotas

Change-Id: Ic2b045549ac0d6112b0c565d2e993576a5626799

> Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1
> 
> (2 comments)
> 
> Paul, thanks for this fix, which looks correct!
> 
> I think your commit message should be improved a bit (see inline remarks) before we merge this though.
> 
> I also wonder (don't know the answer) whether your message should mention the number 2147483647 rather than saying something more generic like "exceeds the maximum allowed range."  Mariadb isn't the only supported database back end for OpenStack so there might be other implementations with different ranges?

Tom, thanks for looking at this!

You do have a point. The integer range limit would only work for implementations working with MariaDB or Postgres.

For the value 2147483647, I got it from the Keystone docs at https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/unified-limits.html#what-is-a-limit maybe adding the value to the message would be more informative to those who would like to know the maximum allowed value.'}, {'account_id': 32635, 'date': '2021-06-29 11:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 32635, 'date': '2021-06-29 12:08:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 32912, 'date': '2021-06-29 12:40:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Adds a clear error message to operator-set limits

When an operator sets a limit that is greater than 2147483647, an
explicit error message "Quota limit should not exceed 2147483647"
is communicated. This is better than the initial error message
which was "ERROR: The server has either erred or is
incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500)."

Closes-Bug: #1908352
Change-Id: I0d301c5f527c3e16e14021b679c85bd51833a1d6

In this spec, Prometheus will be supported as the metrics server.
Tacker installs required packages in Master/Worker nodes for
Prometheus and sends the configuration files describing alert rules
to Prometheus when instantiating Kubernetes cluster VNF.

commit_message:
Alert server for Prometheus with K8s cluster VNF

In this spec, Prometheus will be supported as the metrics server.
Tacker installs required packages in Master/Worker nodes for
Prometheus and sends the configuration files describing alert rules
to Prometheus when instantiating Kubernetes cluster VNF.
Tacker receives alert messages from Prometheus server and invokes
Scale-out/in operations.

commit_message:
Restart octavia rsyslog after updating the config

After creating the octavia rsyslog configuration file, the
octavia_rsyslog container must be restarted if it's already running,
otherwise the new configuration is not applied in the container.

This issue is new, the octavia-ansible playbook was moved from step 5 to
post_deploy, which means that the file is now created after the first start
of the container.

Change-Id: Ibb439d47d551adc5af2d87234b732565af1cc90f

commit_message:
Number of heat queues will keep growing forever after heat-engine restarts

Set TTL as a solution for topic queue engine_worker and heat-engine-listener
to avoid them growing all the time after heat-engin restarts.

This is rabbitmq-server part. eg: we can set heat ttl by:

juju config heat ttl=3600000

Closes-Bug: 1925436
Change-Id: I7b826fe965a200da29020a8f2c6148f76d10a2b0
(cherry picked from commit 707fa0e093af3b6ab636b65b018c29049f7a51ff)
Signed-off-by: Zhang Hua <joshua.zhang@canonical.com>

Set TTL as a solution for topic queue engine_worker and heat-engine-listener
to avoid them growing all the time after heat-engin restarts.

This is heat part.

commit_message:
Switch inventory to directory

Rather than use the generated ansisble inventory.yaml or
tripleo-ansible-inventory.yaml, switch to use the native AnsibleRunner
inventory directory instead.

Change-Id: I74b31d1080fd7b19efbe706024267aa871a6029b

commit_message:
overcloud deploy - net ports with baremetal deploy

--network-ports
  Deploy network ports during baremetal node provisioning.

--network-config (implies --network-ports)
  Deploy network ports and apply the network configuration
  by applying the tripleo_network_config role on the nodes.

Conflicts:
  tripleoclient/v1/overcloud_deploy.py

Change-Id: Ib0c57e57fe5771d914ffd2a93c911cb325152f8b
(cherry picked from commit 05b47bc07ed3ecf1768c5d78929e19538ab8ae85)

Prior to change Ic9db8d852fbfa50f4ac574ebe524c1fb1d85c588
the tripleoclient constants OVERCLOUD_ROLES_FILE and
OVERCLOUD_NETWORKS_FILE was used as the defaults.

commit_message:
Honor role and networks file constants

Prior to change Ic9db8d852fbfa50f4ac574ebe524c1fb1d85c588
the tripleoclient constants OVERCLOUD_ROLES_FILE and
OVERCLOUD_NETWORKS_FILE was used as the defaults.

This was changed to use the defaults in process-templates.py

This restores the previous behaviour, honoring the tripleoclient
constants.

Closes-Bug: #1934010

commit_message:
Migrate back haproxy validation to tripleo-validations

This patch moves back the haproxy validation from validations-common to
tripleo-validations. It has been renamed in tripleo-haproxy and the role
is called now tripleo_haproxy.

This patch also fix the host targeting in order to only execute this
validation on nodes where haproxy is really installed and configured.

Note that the haproxy validations hosted in validations-common will be
removed in a follow up patch.

Closes-Bug: #1926024

Co-Authored-By: Michele Baldessari <michele@redhat.com>

Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I9869afd60342fdb0aca69a313c1c6e35e0947fb8
(cherry picked from commit 9dd662a1b9d5617e1a929c86f6ffdb09e873252b)

commit_message:
Make 'ansible_playbooks' pre-network config only

Distingushing between pre- and post- network config
playbooks is not neccecary. Anything post-network
config can be done using the THT extra config interfaces.

Also, refactor bm post deploy playbooks to utils:
* Add methods in utils module to run playbooks against
  nodes provisioned by the baremetal deploy workflow.
* Re-factors the implementation in node provision to use
  the new methods in utils module.

Conflicts:
  tripleoclient/v2/overcloud_node.py

Change-Id: Ief11590f3421ffd6fb1b4312c07ce9de48f17c3d
(cherry picked from commit c3a8abfdc1f0e66418cf1f9b0db6cd88ebb607c3)

Change-Id: Icc6a7a438e9d0f39d003d1cf8ed84d6fb1d5485a
"}, {'created': '2021-05-14 14:40:29.000000000', 'message': "[WIP]\xa0Extend UC ephemeral heat to export network

Run the commands to export the current stack's

The network, virtual IP definitions and baremeteal deployment
